triples.statement: After the U.S. victory, Mexico recognized U.S. sovereignty over Texas, New Mexico, and California in the 1848 Mexican Cession, which also included lands that would become Nevada, Colorado, and Utah.

triples.sentence: One of the most violent, the [California genocide](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/California_genocide "California genocide") of thousands of Native inhabitants, lasted into the mid-1870s.[[98]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-114)
triples.statement: The California genocide, one of the most violent confrontations, involved thousands of Native inhabitants and lasted into the mid-1870s.

triples.sentence: In Congress, the [Fugitive Slave Act of 1850](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fugitive_Slave_Act_of_1850 "Fugitive Slave Act of 1850") mandated the forcible return to their owners in the South of slaves taking refuge in non-slave states, while the [Kansas–Nebraska Act](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kansas%E2%80%93Nebraska_Act "Kansas–Nebraska Act") of 1854 effectively gutted the anti-slavery requirements of the Missouri Compromise.[[100]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-116)
triples.statement: The Fugitive Slave Act of 1850 mandated the return of slaves who had escaped to non-slave states, while the Kansas–Nebraska Act of 1854 nullified the anti-slavery requirements of the Missouri Compromise.

triples.sentence: Following the [Emancipation Proclamation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emancipation_Proclamation "Emancipation Proclamation") on January 1, 1863, many freed slaves joined the [Union army](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Union_army "Union army").[[107]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-124)
triples.statement: Following the Emancipation Proclamation on January 1, 1863, many freed slaves joined the Union army.

triples.sentence: The war [began to turn in the Union's favor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turning_point_of_the_American_Civil_War "Turning point of the American Civil War") following the 1863 [Siege of Vicksburg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Siege_of_Vicksburg "Siege of Vicksburg") and [Battle of Gettysburg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Gettysburg "Battle of Gettysburg"), and the Confederates surrendered in 1865 after the Union's victory in the [Battle of Appomattox Court House](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Appomattox_Court_House "Battle of Appomattox Court House").[[108]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-125)
triples.statement: The war began to turn in the Union's favor after the 1863 Siege of Vicksburg and Battle of Gettysburg, and the Confederates surrendered in 1865 following the Union's victory at the Battle of Appomattox Court House.

section_path: Reconstruction, Gilded Age, and Progressive Era (1866–1917)
section_body:
Main article: [History of the United States (1865–1917)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_United_States_(1865%E2%80%931917) "History of the United States (1865–1917)")

[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Emigrants_(i.e._immigrants)_landing_at_Ellis_Island_-.webm "Play video")Duration: 2 minutes and 27 seconds.2:27[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Emigrants_(i.e._immigrants)_landing_at_Ellis_Island_-.webm)

An [Edison Studios](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edison_Studios "Edison Studios") film showing immigrants arriving at [Ellis Island](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ellis_Island "Ellis Island") in [New York Harbor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_Harbor "New York Harbor"), a major point of entry for European [immigrants](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Immigration_to_the_United_States "Immigration to the United States") in the late 19th and early 20th centuries[[109]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-PriceBenton-Short2008-126)[[110]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-127)

Efforts toward [reconstruction in the secessionist South](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reconstruction_era "Reconstruction era") had begun as early as 1862,[[111]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDubois1935163-128) but it was only after [President Lincoln's assassination](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assassination_of_Abraham_Lincoln "Assassination of Abraham Lincoln") that the three [Reconstruction Amendments](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reconstruction_Amendments "Reconstruction Amendments") to the Constitution were ratified [to protect civil rights](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Civil_rights_movement_(1865%E2%80%931896) "Civil rights movement (1865–1896)"). The amendments codified nationally the abolition of slavery and involuntary servitude except as punishment for crimes, promised equal protection under the law for all persons, and prohibited discrimination on the basis of race or previous enslavement.[[112]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-129)[[113]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFoner198866-7,_251-261,_446-449-130)[[114]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-131) As a result, African Americans took an active political role in ex-Confederate states in the decade following the Civil War.[[115]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFoner1988xxv-132)[[116]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDubois1935381-727-133) The former Confederate states were readmitted to the Union, beginning with Tennessee in 1866 and ending with Georgia in 1870.[[117]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-134)[[118]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-135)

National infrastructure, including [transcontinental telegraph](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_transcontinental_telegraph "First transcontinental telegraph") and [railroads](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_transcontinental_railroad "First transcontinental railroad"), spurred growth in the [American frontier](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_frontier "American frontier"). This was accelerated by the [Homestead Acts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homestead_Acts "Homestead Acts"), through which nearly 10 percent of the total land area of the United States was given away free to some 1.6 million homesteaders.[[119]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Black2011kj2-136)[[120]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-137) From 1865 through 1917, an unprecedented stream of [immigrants](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Immigrants "Immigrants") arrived in the United States, including 24.4 million from Europe.[[121]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-138) Most came through the [Port of New York](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Port_of_New_York_and_New_Jersey "Port of New York and New Jersey"), and New York City and other large cities on the [East Coast](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/East_Coast_of_the_United_States "East Coast of the United States") became home to large [Jewish](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_the_United_States "History of the Jews in the United States"), [Irish](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Irish_Americans "Irish Americans"), and [Italian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Italian_Americans "Italian Americans") populations. Many [Northern Europeans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northern_Europe "Northern Europe") as well as significant numbers of [Germans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/German_Americans "German Americans") and other [Central Europeans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_Europe "Central Europe") moved to the [Midwest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Midwestern_United_States "Midwestern United States"). At the same time, about one million [French Canadians](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/French-Canadian_Americans "French-Canadian Americans") migrated from [Quebec](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quebec "Quebec") to [New England](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_England "New England").[[122]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-139) During the [Great Migration](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Migration_(African_American) "Great Migration (African American)"), millions of African Americans [left the rural South](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jim_Crow_economy "Jim Crow economy") for urban areas in the North.[[123]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-140)[Alaska was purchased](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alaska_Purchase "Alaska Purchase") from [Russia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russian_Empire "Russian Empire") in 1867.[[124]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-141)

The [Compromise of 1877](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compromise_of_1877 "Compromise of 1877") is generally considered the end of the Reconstruction era, as it resolved the electoral crisis following the [1876 presidential election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1876_United_States_presidential_election "1876 United States presidential election") and led President [Rutherford B. Hayes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rutherford_B._Hayes "Rutherford B. Hayes") to reduce the role of federal troops in the South.[[125]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFoner1988xxvii,_575-587-142) Immediately, the [Redeemers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redeemers "Redeemers") began evicting the [Carpetbaggers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carpetbaggers "Carpetbaggers") and quickly regained local control of Southern politics in the name of [white supremacy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/White_supremacy "White supremacy").[[126]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-143)[[127]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-144) African Americans endured a period of heightened, overt racism following Reconstruction, a time often considered the [nadir of American race relations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nadir_of_American_race_relations "Nadir of American race relations").[[128]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-ReferenceA2-145)[[129]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-146) A series of Supreme Court decisions, including _[Plessy v. Ferguson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plessy\_v.\_Ferguson "Plessy v. Ferguson")_, emptied the [Fourteenth](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fourteenth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution "Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution") and [Fifteenth Amendments](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fifteenth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution "Fifteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution") of their force, allowing [Jim Crow laws](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jim_Crow_laws "Jim Crow laws") in the South to remain unchecked, [sundown towns](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sundown_town "Sundown town") in the Midwest, and [segregation in communities across the country](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Racial_segregation_in_the_United_States "Racial segregation in the United States"), which would be reinforced in part by the policy of [redlining](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redlining "Redlining") later adopted by the federal [Home Owners' Loan Corporation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Home_Owners%27_Loan_Corporation "Home Owners' Loan Corporation").[[130]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-147)

[An explosion of technological advancement](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Second_Industrial_Revolution "Second Industrial Revolution") accompanied by the exploitation of cheap immigrant labor[[131]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-148) led to [rapid economic expansion during the late 19th and early 20th centuries](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gilded_Age "Gilded Age"), allowing the United States to outpace the economies of England, France, and Germany combined.[[132]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-149)[[133]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-150) This fostered the amassing of power by [a few prominent industrialists](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robber_baron_(industrialist) "Robber baron (industrialist)"), largely by their formation of [trusts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trust_(business) "Trust (business)") and [monopolies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monopoly "Monopoly") to prevent competition.[[134]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Atlantic2-151)[Tycoons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tycoon "Tycoon") led the nation's expansion in the [railroad](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_rail_transportation_in_the_United_States "History of rail transportation in the United States"), [petroleum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_petroleum_industry_in_the_United_States "History of the petroleum industry in the United States"), and [steel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_steel_industry_(1850%E2%80%931970) "History of the steel industry (1850–1970)") industries. The United States emerged as a pioneer of the [automotive industry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automotive_industry_in_the_United_States "Automotive industry in the United States").[[135]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-152) These changes resulted in significant increases in [economic inequality](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_inequality "Economic inequality"), [slum conditions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/How_the_Other_Half_Lives "How the Other Half Lives"), and [social unrest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_incidents_of_civil_unrest_in_the_United_States "List of incidents of civil unrest in the United States"), creating the environment for [labor unions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Labor_history_of_the_United_States "Labor history of the United States") and [socialist movements](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_socialist_movement_in_the_United_States "History of the socialist movement in the United States") to begin to flourish.[[136]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-153)[[137]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-154)[[138]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Fraser2-155) This period eventually ended with the advent of the [Progressive Era](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Progressive_Era "Progressive Era"), which was characterized by significant reforms.[[139]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Aldrich2-156)[[140]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-157)

Pro-American elements in Hawaii [overthrew the Hawaiian monarchy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Overthrow_of_the_Hawaiian_Kingdom "Overthrow of the Hawaiian Kingdom"); the islands [were annexed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Newlands_Resolution "Newlands Resolution") in 1898. That same year, [Puerto Rico](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Puerto_Rico "Puerto Rico"), [the Philippines](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Philippines "The Philippines"), and [Guam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guam "Guam") were ceded to the U.S. by Spain after the latter's defeat in the [Spanish–American War](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spanish%E2%80%93American_War "Spanish–American War"). (The Philippines was granted full independence from the U.S. on July 4, 1946, following World War II. Puerto Rico and Guam have remained U.S. territories.)[[141]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-158)[American Samoa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Samoa "American Samoa") was acquired by the United States in 1900 after the [Second Samoan Civil War](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Second_Samoan_Civil_War "Second Samoan Civil War").[[142]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-159) The [U.S. Virgin Islands](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Virgin_Islands "United States Virgin Islands") were purchased from [Denmark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denmark "Denmark") in 1917.[[143]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-160)

triples.sentence: The former Confederate states were readmitted to the Union, beginning with Tennessee in 1866 and ending with Georgia in 1870.[[117]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-134)[[118]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-135)
triples.statement: The former Confederate states were readmitted to the Union between 1866, starting with Tennessee, and 1870, ending with Georgia.

triples.sentence: During the [Great Migration](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Migration_(African_American) "Great Migration (African American)"), millions of African Americans [left the rural South](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jim_Crow_economy "Jim Crow economy") for urban areas in the North.[[123]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-140)
triples.statement: During the Great Migration, millions of African Americans moved from the rural South to urban areas in the North.

triples.sentence: [Alaska was purchased](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alaska_Purchase "Alaska Purchase") from [Russia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russian_Empire "Russian Empire") in 1867.[[124]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-141)
triples.statement: Alaska was purchased from Russia in 1867.

triples.sentence: The United States emerged as a pioneer of the [automotive industry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automotive_industry_in_the_United_States "Automotive industry in the United States").[[135]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-152)
triples.statement: The United States became a pioneer in the automotive industry.

triples.sentence: Puerto Rico and Guam have remained U.S. territories.)[[141]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-158)
triples.statement: Puerto Rico and Guam have continued to be U.S. territories.

triples.sentence: The [U.S. Virgin Islands](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Virgin_Islands "United States Virgin Islands") were purchased from [Denmark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denmark "Denmark") in 1917.[[143]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-160)
triples.statement: The U.S. Virgin Islands were purchased from Denmark in 1917.

section_path: World War I, Great Depression, and World War II (1917–1945)
section_body:
Main article: [History of the United States (1917–1945)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_United_States_(1917%E2%80%931945) "History of the United States (1917–1945)")

[![Image 32](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/Trinity_shot_color_%284x3_cropped%29.jpg/250px-Trinity_shot_color_%284x3_cropped%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Trinity_shot_color_(4x3_cropped).jpg)

The 1945 American [Trinity test](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trinity_(nuclear_test) "Trinity (nuclear test)"), the first-ever detonation of a [nuclear weapon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nuclear_weapon "Nuclear weapon")

The United States [entered World War I](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_entry_into_World_War_I "American entry into World War I") alongside the [Allies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_I "Allies of World War I") in 1917 helping to turn the tide against the [Central Powers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_Powers "Central Powers").[[144]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-161) In 1920, [a constitutional amendment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nineteenth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution "Nineteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution") granted nationwide [women's suffrage](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Women%27s_suffrage_in_the_United_States "Women's suffrage in the United States").[[145]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-162) During the 1920s and 1930s, radio for [mass communication](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mass_communication "Mass communication") and early television transformed communications nationwide.[[146]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWinchester2013410%E2%80%93411-163) The [Wall Street Crash of 1929](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wall_Street_Crash_of_1929 "Wall Street Crash of 1929") triggered the [Great Depression](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Depression_in_the_United_States "Great Depression in the United States"), to which President [Franklin D. Roosevelt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt "Franklin D. Roosevelt") responded with the [New Deal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Deal "New Deal") plan of "reform, recovery and relief", a series of unprecedented and sweeping [recovery programs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alphabet_agencies "Alphabet agencies") and [employment relief projects](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Works_Progress_Administration "Works Progress Administration") combined with [financial reforms and regulations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regulatory_economics "Regulatory economics").[[147]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-164)[[148]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-165)

[Initially neutral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_non-interventionism_before_entering_World_War_II "United States non-interventionism before entering World War II") during [World War II](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Military_history_of_the_United_States_during_World_War_II "Military history of the United States during World War II"), the U.S. began [supplying war materiel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lend-Lease "Lend-Lease") to the [Allies of World War II](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II "Allies of World War II") in March 1941 and [entered the war](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_entry_into_World_War_II "American entry into World War II") in December after [Japan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Empire_of_Japan "Empire of Japan")'s [attack on Pearl Harbor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attack_on_Pearl_Harbor "Attack on Pearl Harbor").[[149]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Pearl_Harbor2-166) Agreeing to a "[Europe first](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Europe_first "Europe first")" policy, the U.S. concentrated its wartime efforts on Japan's allies [Italy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fascist_Italy "Fascist Italy") and [Germany](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nazi_Germany "Nazi Germany") until their final defeat in May 1945. The U.S. [developed the first nuclear weapons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manhattan_Project "Manhattan Project") and [used them against the Japanese cities of Hiroshima and Nagasaki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atomic_bombings_of_Hiroshima_and_Nagasaki "Atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki") in August 1945, ending the war.[[150]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-167)[[151]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-168) The United States was one of the "[Four Policemen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Four_Policemen "Four Policemen")" who met to plan the [post-war world](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aftermath_of_World_War_II "Aftermath of World War II"), alongside the [United Kingdom](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom"), the [Soviet Union](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union"), and [China](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republic_of_China_(1912%E2%80%931949) "Republic of China (1912–1949)").[[152]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHoopesBrinkley1997100-169)[[153]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGaddis197225-170) The U.S. emerged relatively unscathed from the war, with even greater [economic power](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_power "Economic power") and [international political influence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sphere_of_influence "Sphere of influence").[[154]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-171)

triples.sentence: In 1920, [a constitutional amendment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nineteenth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution "Nineteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution") granted nationwide [women's suffrage](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Women%27s_suffrage_in_the_United_States "Women's suffrage in the United States").[[145]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-162)
triples.statement: In 1920, a constitutional amendment granted nationwide women's suffrage.

section_body:
Main articles: [History of the United States (1945–1964)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_United_States_(1945%E2%80%931964) "History of the United States (1945–1964)"), [History of the United States (1964–1980)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_United_States_(1964%E2%80%931980) "History of the United States (1964–1980)"), and [History of the United States (1980–1991)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_United_States_(1980%E2%80%931991) "History of the United States (1980–1991)")

[![Image 33](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Civil_Rights_March_on_Washington%2C_D.C._%28Leaders_marching_from_the_Washington_Monument_to_the_Lincoln_Memorial%29_-_NARA_-_542010.jpg/250px-Civil_Rights_March_on_Washington%2C_D.C._%28Leaders_marching_from_the_Washington_Monument_to_the_Lincoln_Memorial%29_-_NARA_-_542010.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Civil_Rights_March_on_Washington,_D.C._(Leaders_marching_from_the_Washington_Monument_to_the_Lincoln_Memorial)_-_NARA_-_542010.jpg)

Civil rights activists during the [March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/March_on_Washington_for_Jobs_and_Freedom "March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom") in [Washington, D.C.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington,_D.C. "Washington, D.C.") in August 1963

The end of [World War II](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II "World War II") in 1945 left the U.S. and the [Soviet Union](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union") as [superpowers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Superpower "Superpower"), each with its own political, military, and economic [sphere of influence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sphere_of_influence "Sphere of influence"). Geopolitical tensions between the two superpowers soon led to the [Cold War](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cold_War "Cold War").[[155]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Blakemore-20192-172)[[156]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-173)[[157]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-174) The U.S. implemented a policy of [containment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Containment "Containment") intended to limit the Soviet Union's sphere of influence; engaged in [regime change against governments perceived to be aligned with the Soviets](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_involvement_in_regime_change#1945%E2%80%931991:_Cold_War "United States involvement in regime change"); and prevailed in the [Space Race](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Race "Space Race"), which culminated with the [first crewed Moon landing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apollo_11 "Apollo 11") in 1969.[[158]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-175)[[159]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Proxy2-176)

Domestically, the U.S. [experienced economic growth](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Post%E2%80%93World_War_II_economic_expansion "Post–World War II economic expansion"), [urbanization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Urbanization_in_the_United_States "Urbanization in the United States"), and [population growth following World War II](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mid-20th_century_baby_boom "Mid-20th century baby boom").[[160]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWinchester2013305%E2%80%93308-177) The [civil rights movement](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Civil_rights_movement "Civil rights movement") emerged, with [Martin Luther King Jr.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Luther_King_Jr. "Martin Luther King Jr.") becoming a prominent leader in the early 1960s.[[161]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-178) The [Great Society](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Society "Great Society") plan of President [Lyndon B. Johnson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyndon_B._Johnson "Lyndon B. Johnson")'s administration resulted in groundbreaking and broad-reaching laws, policies and [a constitutional amendment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twenty-fourth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution "Twenty-fourth Amendment to the United States Constitution") to counteract some of the worst effects of lingering [institutional racism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Institutional_racism "Institutional racism").[[162]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-179)

The [counterculture movement](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Counterculture_of_the_1960s "Counterculture of the 1960s") in the U.S. brought significant social changes, including the liberalization of attitudes toward [recreational drug use](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Recreational_drug_use "Recreational drug use") and [sexuality](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sexual_revolution "Sexual revolution").[[163]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-180)[[164]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-181) It also encouraged [open defiance of the military draft](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Draft_evasion_in_the_Vietnam_War "Draft evasion in the Vietnam War") (leading to the [end of conscription](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conscription_in_the_United_States "Conscription in the United States") in 1973)[[165]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-182) and [wide opposition](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opposition_to_United_States_involvement_in_the_Vietnam_War "Opposition to United States involvement in the Vietnam War") to [U.S. intervention in Vietnam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_in_the_Vietnam_War "United States in the Vietnam War"), with the U.S. totally withdrawing in 1975.[[166]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-183)[A societal shift in the roles of women](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Women%27s_liberation_movement_in_the_United_States "Women's liberation movement in the United States") was significantly responsible for the large increase in female paid labor participation starting in the 1970s, and by 1985 the majority of American women aged 16 and older were employed.[[167]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-184)

The [Fall of Communism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Revolutions_of_1989 "Revolutions of 1989") and the [dissolution of the Soviet Union](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dissolution_of_the_Soviet_Union "Dissolution of the Soviet Union") from 1989 to 1991 marked the [end of the Cold War](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/End_of_the_Cold_War "End of the Cold War") and [left the United States as the world's sole superpower](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Superpower#After_the_Cold_War "Superpower").[[168]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Gaidar2-185)[[169]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-186)[[170]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-187)[[171]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-188) This cemented the United States' global influence, reinforcing the concept of the "[American Century](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Century "American Century")" as the U.S. dominated international political, cultural, economic, and military affairs.[[172]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-189)[[173]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-190)

triples.sentence: The [civil rights movement](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Civil_rights_movement "Civil rights movement") emerged, with [Martin Luther King Jr.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Luther_King_Jr. "Martin Luther King Jr.") becoming a prominent leader in the early 1960s.[[161]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-178)
triples.statement: The civil rights movement emerged, with Martin Luther King Jr. becoming a prominent leader in the early 1960s.

triples.sentence: It also encouraged [open defiance of the military draft](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Draft_evasion_in_the_Vietnam_War "Draft evasion in the Vietnam War") (leading to the [end of conscription](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conscription_in_the_United_States "Conscription in the United States") in 1973)[[165]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-182) and [wide opposition](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opposition_to_United_States_involvement_in_the_Vietnam_War "Opposition to United States involvement in the Vietnam War") to [U.S. intervention in Vietnam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_in_the_Vietnam_War "United States in the Vietnam War"), with the U.S. totally withdrawing in 1975.[[166]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-183)
triples.statement: The counterculture movement also encouraged open defiance of the military draft, leading to the end of conscription in 1973, and wide opposition to U.S. intervention in Vietnam, from which the U.S. withdrew in 1975.

triples.sentence: [A societal shift in the roles of women](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Women%27s_liberation_movement_in_the_United_States "Women's liberation movement in the United States") was significantly responsible for the large increase in female paid labor participation starting in the 1970s, and by 1985 the majority of American women aged 16 and older were employed.[[167]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-184)
triples.statement: A societal shift in women's roles was a major factor in the large increase in female paid labor participation beginning in the 1970s, and by 1985, the majority of American women aged 16 and older were employed.

triples.sentence: This cemented the United States' global influence, reinforcing the concept of the "[American Century](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Century "American Century")" as the U.S. dominated international political, cultural, economic, and military affairs.[[172]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-189)[[173]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-190)
triples.statement: This event cemented the United States' global influence and reinforced the concept of the "American Century," with the U.S. dominating international political, cultural, economic, and military affairs.

section_body:
Main articles: [History of the United States (1991–2016)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_United_States_(1991%E2%80%932016) "History of the United States (1991–2016)") and [History of the United States (2016–present)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_United_States_(2016%E2%80%93present) "History of the United States (2016–present)")

[![Image 34](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/WTC_smoking_on_9-11.jpeg/250px-WTC_smoking_on_9-11.jpeg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:WTC_smoking_on_9-11.jpeg)

The [Twin Towers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Trade_Center_(1973%E2%80%932001) "World Trade Center (1973–2001)") in New York City during the [September 11 attacks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/September_11_attacks "September 11 attacks") of 2001

The 1990s saw the [longest recorded economic expansion in American history](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1990s_United_States_boom "1990s United States boom"), a dramatic [decline in U.S. crime rates](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crime_in_the_United_States#Crime_over_time "Crime in the United States"), and [advances in technology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_and_industrial_history_of_the_United_States#Computers_and_information_networks "Technological and industrial history of the United States"). Throughout this decade, technological innovations such as the [World Wide Web](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web "World Wide Web"), the evolution of the [Pentium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pentium_(original) "Pentium (original)") microprocessor in accordance with [Moore's law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moore%27s_law "Moore's law"), rechargeable [lithium-ion batteries](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lithium-ion_battery "Lithium-ion battery"), the first [gene therapy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gene_therapy "Gene therapy") trial, and [cloning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cloning "Cloning") either emerged in the U.S. or were improved upon there. The [Human Genome Project](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_Genome_Project "Human Genome Project") was formally launched in 1990, while [Nasdaq](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nasdaq "Nasdaq") became the first stock market in the United States to trade online in 1998.[[174]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-191)

In the [Gulf War](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gulf_War "Gulf War") of 1991, [an American-led international coalition of states](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coalition_of_the_Gulf_War "Coalition of the Gulf War") expelled an [Iraqi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ba%27athist_Iraq "Ba'athist Iraq") invasion force that had occupied neighboring [Kuwait](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kuwait "Kuwait").[[175]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-192) The [September 11 attacks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/September_11_attacks "September 11 attacks") on the United States in 2001 by the [pan-Islamist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pan-Islamism "Pan-Islamism") militant organization [al-Qaeda](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Al-Qaeda "Al-Qaeda") led to the [war on terror](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/War_on_terror "War on terror") and subsequent [military interventions in Afghanistan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/War_in_Afghanistan_(2001%E2%80%932021) "War in Afghanistan (2001–2021)") and [in Iraq](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iraq_War "Iraq War").[[176]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-193)[[177]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-194)

The [U.S. housing bubble](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2000s_United_States_housing_bubble "2000s United States housing bubble") culminated in 2007 with the [Great Recession](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Recession "Great Recession"), the largest economic contraction since the Great Depression.[[178]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-195) In the 2010s and early 2020s, the United States has experienced increased [political polarization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_polarization_in_the_United_States "Political polarization in the United States") and [democratic backsliding](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_backsliding_in_the_United_States "Democratic backsliding in the United States").[[179]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-196)[[180]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-197)[[181]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-198)[[182]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-199) The country's polarization was violently reflected in the [January 2021 Capitol attack](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/January_6_United_States_Capitol_attack "January 6 United States Capitol attack"),[[183]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Kleinfeld-2023-200) when a mob of insurrectionists[[184]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Pape-2022-201) entered the [U.S. Capitol](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Capitol "United States Capitol") and sought to prevent the peaceful transfer of power[[185]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-202) in an [attempted self-coup d'état](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-coup#Notable_events_described_as_attempted_self-coups "Self-coup").[[186]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Multiple_Sources-203)

triples.sentence: The [Human Genome Project](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_Genome_Project "Human Genome Project") was formally launched in 1990, while [Nasdaq](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nasdaq "Nasdaq") became the first stock market in the United States to trade online in 1998.[[174]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-191)
triples.statement: The Human Genome Project was launched in 1990, and Nasdaq became the first U.S. stock market to trade online in 1998.

triples.sentence: The [September 11 attacks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/September_11_attacks "September 11 attacks") on the United States in 2001 by the [pan-Islamist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pan-Islamism "Pan-Islamism") militant organization [al-Qaeda](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Al-Qaeda "Al-Qaeda") led to the [war on terror](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/War_on_terror "War on terror") and subsequent [military interventions in Afghanistan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/War_in_Afghanistan_(2001%E2%80%932021) "War in Afghanistan (2001–2021)") and [in Iraq](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iraq_War "Iraq War").[[176]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-193)[[177]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-194)
triples.statement: The September 11 attacks in 2001 by al-Qaeda led to the war on terror and subsequent U.S. military interventions in Afghanistan and Iraq.

triples.sentence: The [U.S. housing bubble](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2000s_United_States_housing_bubble "2000s United States housing bubble") culminated in 2007 with the [Great Recession](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Recession "Great Recession"), the largest economic contraction since the Great Depression.[[178]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-195)
triples.statement: The U.S. housing bubble culminated in 2007 with the Great Recession, which was the largest economic contraction since the Great Depression.

triples.sentence: In the 2010s and early 2020s, the United States has experienced increased [political polarization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_polarization_in_the_United_States "Political polarization in the United States") and [democratic backsliding](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_backsliding_in_the_United_States "Democratic backsliding in the United States").[[179]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-196)[[180]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-197)[[181]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-198)[[182]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-199)
triples.statement: In the 2010s and early 2020s, the United States has seen increased political polarization and democratic backsliding.

section_body:
Main article: [Geography of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geography_of_the_United_States "Geography of the United States")

[![Image 35](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Uspaintedrelief.png/250px-Uspaintedrelief.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Uspaintedrelief.png)

A [topographic map](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topographic_map "Topographic map") of the United States

The United States is the world's [third-largest country](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_area "List of countries and dependencies by area") by total area behind Russia and Canada.[[c]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-largestcountry-15) The 48 [contiguous states and the District of Columbia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Contiguous_United_States "Contiguous United States") have a combined area of 3,119,885 square miles (8,080,470 km 2).[[12]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-CensusGov2010HTML-14)[[187]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-204) In 2021, the United States had 8% of the Earth's permanent meadows and pastures and 10% of its cropland.[[188]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Food_and_Agriculture_Organization_of_the_United_Nations-2023-205)

Starting in the east, [the coastal plain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atlantic_Plain "Atlantic Plain") of the [Atlantic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean "Atlantic Ocean") seaboard gives way to inland forests and rolling hills in the [Piedmont](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Piedmont_(United_States) "Piedmont (United States)") plateau region.[[189]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-206) The [Appalachian Mountains](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Appalachian_Mountains "Appalachian Mountains") and the [Adirondack Massif](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adirondack_Mountains "Adirondack Mountains") separate the [East Coast](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/East_Coast_of_the_United_States "East Coast of the United States") from the [Great Lakes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Lakes "Great Lakes") and the grasslands of [the Midwest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Midwestern_United_States "Midwestern United States").[[190]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-NAU-207) The [Mississippi River System](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mississippi_River_System "Mississippi River System"), the world's [fourth-longest river system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_rivers_by_length "List of rivers by length"), runs predominantly north–south through the center of the country. The flat and fertile [prairie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prairie "Prairie") of the [Great Plains](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Plains "Great Plains") stretches to the west, interrupted by [a highland region](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.S._Interior_Highlands "U.S. Interior Highlands") in the southeast.[[190]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-NAU-207)

[![Image 36](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Canyon_River_Tree_%28165872763%29.jpeg/250px-Canyon_River_Tree_%28165872763%29.jpeg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Canyon_River_Tree_(165872763).jpeg)

The [Grand Canyon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_Canyon "Grand Canyon") in Arizona

The [Rocky Mountains](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rocky_Mountains "Rocky Mountains"), west of the Great Plains, extend north to south across the country, peaking at over 14,000 feet (4,300 m) in [Colorado](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Colorado "Colorado").[[191]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-208) The [supervolcano](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supervolcano "Supervolcano") underlying [Yellowstone National Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yellowstone_National_Park "Yellowstone National Park") in the Rocky Mountains, the [Yellowstone Caldera](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yellowstone_Caldera "Yellowstone Caldera"), is the continent's largest volcanic feature.[[192]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-209) Farther west are the rocky [Great Basin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Basin "Great Basin") and the [Chihuahuan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chihuahuan_Desert "Chihuahuan Desert"), [Sonoran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sonoran_Desert "Sonoran Desert"), and [Mojave](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mojave_Desert "Mojave Desert") deserts.[[193]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-210) In the northwest corner of [Arizona](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arizona "Arizona"), carved by the [Colorado River](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Colorado_River "Colorado River"), is the [Grand Canyon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_Canyon "Grand Canyon"), a steep-sided canyon and popular tourist destination[[194]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-211) known for its overwhelming visual size and intricate, colorful landscape. The [Cascade](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cascade_Range "Cascade Range") and [Sierra Nevada](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sierra_Nevada "Sierra Nevada") mountain ranges run close to the [Pacific coast](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/West_Coast_of_the_United_States "West Coast of the United States"). The [lowest and highest points in the contiguous United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extreme_points_of_the_United_States "Extreme points of the United States") are in the State of California,[[195]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-212) about 84 miles (135 km) apart.[[196]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-213)

At an elevation of 20,310 feet (6,190.5 m), Alaska's [Denali](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denali "Denali") (also called Mount McKinley) is the highest peak in the country and on the continent.[[197]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-214) Active [volcanoes in the U.S.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_volcanoes_in_the_United_States "List of volcanoes in the United States") are common throughout Alaska's [Alexander](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexander_Archipelago "Alexander Archipelago") and [Aleutian Islands](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleutian_Islands "Aleutian Islands"). Located entirely outside North America, the archipelago of Hawaii consists of volcanic islands, [physiographically](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Physical_geography "Physical geography") and [ethnologically](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethnology "Ethnology") part of the [Polynesian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polynesia "Polynesia") subregion of [Oceania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oceania "Oceania").[[198]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-215)

In addition to its total land area, the United States has one of the world's largest marine [exclusive economic zones](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exclusive_economic_zones "Exclusive economic zones") spanning approximately 4.5 million square miles (11.7 million km 2) of ocean.[[199]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-216)[[200]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-217)

triples.statement: The 48 contiguous states and the District of Columbia have a combined area of 3,119,885 square miles (8,080,470 km 2).

section_body:
Main article: [Climate of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Climate_of_the_United_States "Climate of the United States")

[![Image 37](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/K%C3%B6ppen_Climate_Types_US_50.png/250px-K%C3%B6ppen_Climate_Types_US_50.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:K%C3%B6ppen_Climate_Types_US_50.png)

The [Köppen climate types](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification "Köppen climate classification") of the United States

With its large size and geographic variety, the United States includes most climate types. East of the [100th meridian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/100th_meridian_west "100th meridian west"), the climate ranges from [humid continental](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Humid_continental_climate "Humid continental climate") in the north to [humid subtropical](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Humid_subtropical_climate "Humid subtropical climate") in the south.[[201]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-218) The western Great Plains are [semi-arid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semi-arid_climate "Semi-arid climate").[[202]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-219) Many mountainous areas of the American West have an [alpine climate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alpine_climate "Alpine climate"). The climate is [arid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Desert_climate "Desert climate") in the Southwest, [Mediterranean](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mediterranean_climate "Mediterranean climate") in [coastal California](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coastal_California "Coastal California"), and [oceanic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oceanic_climate "Oceanic climate") in coastal [Oregon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oregon "Oregon"), [Washington](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_(state) "Washington (state)"), and southern [Alaska](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alaska "Alaska"). Most of Alaska is [subarctic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subarctic_climate "Subarctic climate") or [polar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polar_climate "Polar climate"). [Hawaii](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hawaii "Hawaii"), the [southern tip of Florida](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Florida "South Florida") and U.S. territories in the [Caribbean](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Caribbean "Caribbean") and [Pacific](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Ocean "Pacific Ocean") are [tropical](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tropical_climate "Tropical climate").[[203]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-220)

The United States receives more high-impact [extreme weather](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extreme_weather "Extreme weather") incidents than any other country.[[204]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-221)[[205]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-222) States bordering the [Gulf of Mexico](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gulf_of_Mexico "Gulf of Mexico") are prone to hurricanes, and most of the world's tornadoes [occur in the country](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tornadoes_in_the_United_States "Tornadoes in the United States"), mainly in [Tornado Alley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tornado_Alley "Tornado Alley").[[206]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-223) Due to [climate change in the country](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Climate_change_in_the_United_States "Climate change in the United States"), extreme weather has become more frequent in the U.S. in the 21st century, with three times the number of reported [heat waves](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heat_waves "Heat waves") compared to the 1960s.[[207]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-224)[[208]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-225)[[209]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-226) Since the 1990s, droughts in the [American Southwest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Southwestern_United_States "Southwestern United States") have become more persistent and more severe.[[210]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-227) The regions considered as the most attractive to the population are the most vulnerable.[[211]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-228)

triples.statement: The western Great Plains have a semi-arid climate.
