section_body:
Main articles: [Fauna of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fauna_of_the_United_States "Fauna of the United States") and [Flora of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flora_of_the_United_States "Flora of the United States")

[![Image 38: A bald eagle](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Bald_eagle_about_to_fly_in_Alaska_%282016%29.jpg/250px-Bald_eagle_about_to_fly_in_Alaska_%282016%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Bald_eagle_about_to_fly_in_Alaska_(2016).jpg)

The [bald eagle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bald_eagle "Bald eagle"), the [national emblem of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bald_eagle#National_symbol_of_the_United_States "Bald eagle") since 1782 and officially declared the national bird in 2024[[212]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-229)

The U.S. is one of 17 [megadiverse countries](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Megadiverse_countries "Megadiverse countries") containing large numbers of [endemic species](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_endangered_animals_of_North_America "List of endangered animals of North America"): about 17,000 species of [vascular plants](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vascular_plant "Vascular plant") occur in the contiguous United States and Alaska, and over 1,800 species of [flowering plants](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flowering_plant "Flowering plant") are found in Hawaii, few of which occur on the mainland.[[213]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-230) The United States is home to 428 [mammal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mammal "Mammal") species, 784 birds, 311 reptiles, 295 [amphibians](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amphibian "Amphibian"),[[214]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Current_Results_#_of_native_species_in_the_US-231) and around 91,000 insect species.[[215]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-232)

There are [63 national parks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_national_parks_of_the_United_States "List of national parks of the United States"), and [hundreds of other federally managed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_lands "Federal lands") monuments, forests, and [wilderness areas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Wilderness_Preservation_System "National Wilderness Preservation System"), administered by the [National Park Service](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Park_Service "National Park Service") and other agencies.[[216]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-233) About 28% of the country's land is publicly owned and federally managed,[[217]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-NYTimes_Federal_Land-234) primarily in the [Western States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Western_United_States "Western United States").[[218]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-AKLeg_CRS_Federal_Land-235)[Most of this land is protected](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Protected_areas_of_the_United_States "Protected areas of the United States"), though some is leased for commercial use, and less than one percent is used for military purposes.[[219]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Federal_Land_Ownership-236)[[220]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Fed_Land_Uses-237)

[Environmental issues in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Environmental_issues_in_the_United_States "Environmental issues in the United States") include debates on [non-renewable resources](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-renewable_resource "Non-renewable resource") and [nuclear energy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nuclear_power_debate "Nuclear power debate"), [air and water pollution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pollution_prevention_in_the_US "Pollution prevention in the US"), [biodiversity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biodiversity "Biodiversity"), logging and [deforestation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deforestation_in_the_United_States "Deforestation in the United States"),[[221]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-238)[[222]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-239) and [climate change](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Climate_change_in_the_United_States "Climate change in the United States").[[223]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-240)[[224]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-241) The [U.S. Environmental Protection Agency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Environmental_Protection_Agency "United States Environmental Protection Agency") (EPA) is the federal agency charged with [addressing most environmental-related issues](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Environmental_policy_of_the_United_States "Environmental policy of the United States").[[225]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Collin2006-242) The [idea of wilderness](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Wilderness_Preservation_System "National Wilderness Preservation System") has shaped the management of public lands since 1964, with the [Wilderness Act](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wilderness_Act "Wilderness Act").[[226]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-243) The [Endangered Species Act of 1973](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Endangered_Species_Act_of_1973 "Endangered Species Act of 1973") provides a way to protect threatened and endangered species and their habitats. The [United States Fish and Wildlife Service](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Fish_and_Wildlife_Service "United States Fish and Wildlife Service") implements and enforces the Act.[[227]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Office-244) In 2024, the U.S. ranked 35th among 180 countries in the [Environmental Performance Index](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Environmental_Performance_Index "Environmental Performance Index").[[228]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-245)

triples.sentence: The [bald eagle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bald_eagle "Bald eagle"), the [national emblem of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bald_eagle#National_symbol_of_the_United_States "Bald eagle") since 1782 and officially declared the national bird in 2024[[212]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-229)
triples.statement: The bald eagle has been the national emblem of the United States since 1782 and was officially declared the national bird in 2024.

triples.sentence: The U.S. is one of 17 [megadiverse countries](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Megadiverse_countries "Megadiverse countries") containing large numbers of [endemic species](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_endangered_animals_of_North_America "List of endangered animals of North America"): about 17,000 species of [vascular plants](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vascular_plant "Vascular plant") occur in the contiguous United States and Alaska, and over 1,800 species of [flowering plants](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flowering_plant "Flowering plant") are found in Hawaii, few of which occur on the mainland.[[213]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-230)
triples.statement: The U.S. is one of 17 megadiverse countries, with about 17,000 species of vascular plants in the contiguous U.S. and Alaska, and over 1,800 species of flowering plants in Hawaii.

triples.sentence: The United States is home to 428 [mammal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mammal "Mammal") species, 784 birds, 311 reptiles, 295 [amphibians](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amphibian "Amphibian"),[[214]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Current_Results_#_of_native_species_in_the_US-231) and around 91,000 insect species.[[215]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-232)
triples.statement: The United States is home to 428 mammal species, 784 bird species, 311 reptile species, 295 amphibian species, and around 91,000 insect species.

triples.sentence: There are [63 national parks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_national_parks_of_the_United_States "List of national parks of the United States"), and [hundreds of other federally managed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_lands "Federal lands") monuments, forests, and [wilderness areas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Wilderness_Preservation_System "National Wilderness Preservation System"), administered by the [National Park Service](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Park_Service "National Park Service") and other agencies.[[216]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-233)
triples.statement: There are 63 national parks and hundreds of other federally managed monuments, forests, and wilderness areas, which are administered by the National Park Service and other agencies.

triples.sentence: About 28% of the country's land is publicly owned and federally managed,[[217]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-NYTimes_Federal_Land-234) primarily in the [Western States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Western_United_States "Western United States").[[218]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-AKLeg_CRS_Federal_Land-235)
triples.statement: About 28% of U.S. land is publicly owned and federally managed, mostly in the Western States.

triples.sentence: [Most of this land is protected](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Protected_areas_of_the_United_States "Protected areas of the United States"), though some is leased for commercial use, and less than one percent is used for military purposes.[[219]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Federal_Land_Ownership-236)[[220]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Fed_Land_Uses-237)
triples.statement: Most of the federally managed land is protected, though some is leased for commercial use and less than one percent is used for military purposes.

triples.sentence: The [U.S. Environmental Protection Agency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Environmental_Protection_Agency "United States Environmental Protection Agency") (EPA) is the federal agency charged with [addressing most environmental-related issues](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Environmental_policy_of_the_United_States "Environmental policy of the United States").[[225]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Collin2006-242)
triples.statement: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) is the federal agency responsible for addressing most environmental-related issues.

triples.sentence: In 2024, the U.S. ranked 35th among 180 countries in the [Environmental Performance Index](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Environmental_Performance_Index "Environmental Performance Index").[[228]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-245)
triples.statement: In 2024, the U.S. was ranked 35th out of 180 countries on the Environmental Performance Index.

section_body:
Main article: [Politics of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Politics_of_the_United_States "Politics of the United States")

[![Image 39](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/United_States_Capitol_west_front_edit2.jpg/250px-United_States_Capitol_west_front_edit2.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:United_States_Capitol_west_front_edit2.jpg)

The [Capitol Building](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Capitol "United States Capitol"), seat of legislative government, houses both chambers of [Congress](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.S._Congress "U.S. Congress").

[![Image 40](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/White_House_lawn_%28long_tightly_cropped%29.jpg/250px-White_House_lawn_%28long_tightly_cropped%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:White_House_lawn_(long_tightly_cropped).jpg)

The [White House](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/White_House "White House"), residence and workplace of the president, includes offices for [the executive staff](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Executive_Office_of_the_President_of_the_United_States "Executive Office of the President of the United States").

[![Image 41](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Panorama_of_United_States_Supreme_Court_Building_at_Dusk.jpg/250px-Panorama_of_United_States_Supreme_Court_Building_at_Dusk.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Panorama_of_United_States_Supreme_Court_Building_at_Dusk.jpg)

The [Supreme Court Building](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Supreme_Court_Building "United States Supreme Court Building") houses the [nation's highest court](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States "Supreme Court of the United States").

The United States is a [federal republic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_republic "Federal republic") of 50 [states](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.S._state "U.S. state") and a federal capital district, [Washington, D.C.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington,_D.C. "Washington, D.C.") The U.S. asserts sovereignty over five [unincorporated territories](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Territories_of_the_United_States "Territories of the United States") and [several uninhabited island possessions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Minor_Outlying_Islands "United States Minor Outlying Islands").[[19]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-HRI-2012-28)[[229]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOnuf2010xvii-246) It is the world's oldest surviving federation,[[230]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-247) and its [presidential system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Presidential_system "Presidential system") of national government has been adopted, in whole or in part, by many newly independent states worldwide following their [decolonization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decolonization "Decolonization").[[231]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-248) The [Constitution of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constitution_of_the_United_States "Constitution of the United States") serves as [the country's supreme legal document](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supremacy_Clause "Supremacy Clause").[[232]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-249) Most scholars describe the United States as a [liberal democracy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liberal_democracy "Liberal democracy").[[233]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Scheb-250)[[r]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-262)

triples.sentence: The [Constitution of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constitution_of_the_United_States "Constitution of the United States") serves as [the country's supreme legal document](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supremacy_Clause "Supremacy Clause").[[232]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-249)
triples.statement: The Constitution of the United States serves as the country's supreme legal document.

section_body:
Main article: [Federal government of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_government_of_the_United_States "Federal government of the United States")

Composed of three branches, all headquartered in Washington, D.C., the federal government is the national government of the United States. The [U.S. Constitution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.S._Constitution "U.S. Constitution") establishes a [separation of powers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Separation_of_powers "Separation of powers") intended to provide a system of [checks and balances](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Checks_and_balances "Checks and balances") to prevent any of the three branches from becoming supreme.[[245]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-263)

*   The [U.S. Congress](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Congress "United States Congress") is a [bicameral legislature](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bicameral_legislature "Bicameral legislature") made up of the [Senate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Senate "United States Senate") and the [House of Representatives](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_House_of_Representatives "United States House of Representatives"). The Senate has 100 members—two residents from each state and elected by that state's voters for a six-year term. The House of Representatives has 435 members, elected for a two-year term by the constituency of the [congressional district](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_United_States_congressional_districts "List of United States congressional districts") where they reside. A [state's legislature](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_legislature_(United_States) "State legislature (United States)") decides the district boundaries, which are contiguous within the state. Every U.S. congressional district is of equivalent population and sends one representative to Congress.[[246]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-264) Election years for senators are staggered so that only one-third of them will be up for election every two years.[[247]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-265) U.S. representatives are all up for election at the same time every two years. The U.S. Congress makes [federal law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_law "Federal law"), [declares war](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Declaration_of_war "Declaration of war"), approves treaties, has the [power of the purse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Power_of_the_purse "Power of the purse"),[[248]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-266) and has [the power of impeachment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Impeachment_in_the_United_States "Impeachment in the United States").[[249]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-267) One of its foremost non-legislative functions is [the power to investigate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Congressional_investigation "Congressional investigation") and oversee the executive branch.[[250]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-tws2010Sep11t11-268)[Congressional oversight](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Congressional_oversight "Congressional oversight") is usually delegated to committees and is facilitated by [Congress's power to issue subpoenas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Contempt_of_Congress "Contempt of Congress").[[251]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-tws2010Sep11t13-269) Much of the work of Congress is performed by [a collection of committees](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_congressional_committee "United States congressional committee"), each appointed for a specific purpose or function. Committee membership is by tradition and statute [bipartisan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bipartisan "Bipartisan"), but all committees are [chaired](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chair_(officer) "Chair (officer)") by a member of the [majority party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Majority_party "Majority party"), who sets the committee agenda.[[252]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-270)

[![Image 42](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Official_Presidential_Portrait_of_President_Donald_J._Trump_%282025%29.jpg/250px-Official_Presidential_Portrait_of_President_Donald_J._Trump_%282025%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Official_Presidential_Portrait_of_President_Donald_J._Trump_(2025).jpg)

[Donald Trump](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump "Donald Trump")

[President](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/President_of_the_United_States "President of the United States")

[![Image 43](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/January_2025_Official_Vice_Presidential_Portrait_of_JD_Vance.jpg/250px-January_2025_Official_Vice_Presidential_Portrait_of_JD_Vance.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:January_2025_Official_Vice_Presidential_Portrait_of_JD_Vance.jpg)

[JD Vance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/JD_Vance "JD Vance")

[Vice President](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vice_President_of_the_United_States "Vice President of the United States")

*   The U.S. president is the [head of state](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Head_of_state "Head of state"), [commander-in-chief](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commander-in-chief "Commander-in-chief") of the military, [chief executive of the federal government](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Head_of_government "Head of government"), and has the ability to veto [legislative bills](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_(law) "Bill (law)") from the U.S. Congress before they become law. However, [presidential vetoes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Veto_power_in_the_United_States "Veto power in the United States") can be overridden by a two-thirds [supermajority](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supermajority#Use_in_governments_around_the_world "Supermajority") vote in both chambers of Congress. The president appoints the [members of the Cabinet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cabinet_of_the_United_States "Cabinet of the United States"), subject to Senate approval, and names other officials who administer and enforce federal law and policy through [their respective agencies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_federal_agencies_in_the_United_States "List of federal agencies in the United States").[[253]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-271) The president also has clemency power for federal crimes and [can issue pardons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_pardons_in_the_United_States "Federal pardons in the United States"). Finally, the president has the authority to issue expansive "[executive orders](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Executive_orders "Executive orders")" in a number of policy areas, subject to [judicial review](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Judicial_review_in_the_United_States "Judicial review in the United States"). Candidates for president campaign with a vice-presidential [running mate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Running_mate "Running mate"). Both candidates are elected together, or defeated together, in a presidential election. Unlike other votes in American politics, this is technically an [indirect election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indirect_election "Indirect election") in which the winner will be determined by the [U.S. Electoral College](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Electoral_College "United States Electoral College"). There, votes are officially cast by individual electors selected by [their state legislature](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_legislature_(United_States) "State legislature (United States)").[[254]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-272) In practice, however, each of the 50 states chooses a group of presidential electors who are required by state law to confirm the winner of their state's popular vote. Each state is allocated two electors plus one additional elector for every congressional district in the state, which in effect combines to equal the number of elected officials that state sends to Congress. The District of Columbia, with no representatives or senators, is allocated three electoral votes. Both the president and the vice president serve a four-year term, and the president may be [reelected to the office only once](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twenty-second_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution "Twenty-second Amendment to the United States Constitution"), for one additional four-year term.[[s]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-273)
*   The [U.S. federal judiciary](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_judiciary_of_the_United_States "Federal judiciary of the United States"), whose judges are all appointed for life by the president with Senate approval, consists primarily of the [U.S. Supreme Court](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States "Supreme Court of the United States"), the [U.S. courts of appeals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_courts_of_appeals "United States courts of appeals"), and the [U.S. district courts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_district_court "United States district court"). The lowest level in the federal judiciary is the federal district court, which decides all cases considered to be under "[original jurisdiction](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Original_jurisdiction#Federal_and_state_courts "Original jurisdiction")", such as federal statutes, constitutional law, or [international treaties](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_treaties "International treaties"). After a federal district court has decided a case, its decision may be contested and sent to a higher court, a federal court of appeals. The U.S. judicial system's 12 federal circuits divide the country into 12 separate geographic administrative regions for appeals decisions. The next and highest court in the system is the Supreme Court of the United States.[[255]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FedJud-274) The U.S. Supreme Court interprets laws and [overturns those it finds unconstitutional](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Judicial_review "Judicial review").[[255]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FedJud-274) On average, the Supreme Court receives about 7,000 appeals petitions for [writs of certiorari](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Writs_of_certiorari "Writs of certiorari") each year, but only grants about 80.[[256]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-275) Consisting of nine members led by the [Chief Justice of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chief_Justice_of_the_United_States "Chief Justice of the United States"), the court judges each case before it by majority decision. As with all other federal judges, the members are appointed for life by the sitting president with Senate approval when a vacancy becomes available.[[257]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-276)

The three-branch system is known as the [presidential system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Presidential_system "Presidential system"), in contrast to the [parliamentary system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parliamentary_system "Parliamentary system") where the executive is part of the legislative body. Many countries around the world adopted this aspect of the 1789 Constitution of the United States, especially in the [postcolonial](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Postcolonialism "Postcolonialism") Americas.[[258]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Sundquist-277)

triples.sentence: The [U.S. Constitution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.S._Constitution "U.S. Constitution") establishes a [separation of powers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Separation_of_powers "Separation of powers") intended to provide a system of [checks and balances](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Checks_and_balances "Checks and balances") to prevent any of the three branches from becoming supreme.[[245]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-263)
triples.statement: The U.S. Constitution establishes a separation of powers with a system of checks and balances to prevent any of the three government branches from becoming supreme.

triples.sentence: Every U.S. congressional district is of equivalent population and sends one representative to Congress.[[246]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-264)
triples.statement: Each U.S. congressional district has an equivalent population and elects one representative to Congress.

triples.sentence: The U.S. Congress makes [federal law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_law "Federal law"), [declares war](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Declaration_of_war "Declaration of war"), approves treaties, has the [power of the purse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Power_of_the_purse "Power of the purse"),[[248]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-266) and has [the power of impeachment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Impeachment_in_the_United_States "Impeachment in the United States").[[249]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-267)
triples.statement: The U.S. Congress has the power to make federal law, declare war, approve treaties, control funding (power of the purse), and impeach officials.

triples.sentence: One of its foremost non-legislative functions is [the power to investigate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Congressional_investigation "Congressional investigation") and oversee the executive branch.[[250]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-tws2010Sep11t11-268)
triples.statement: A primary non-legislative function of Congress is the power to investigate and oversee the executive branch.

triples.sentence: [Congressional oversight](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Congressional_oversight "Congressional oversight") is usually delegated to committees and is facilitated by [Congress's power to issue subpoenas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Contempt_of_Congress "Contempt of Congress").[[251]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-tws2010Sep11t13-269)
triples.statement: Congressional oversight is typically delegated to committees and supported by the power to issue subpoenas.

triples.sentence: The president appoints the [members of the Cabinet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cabinet_of_the_United_States "Cabinet of the United States"), subject to Senate approval, and names other officials who administer and enforce federal law and policy through [their respective agencies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_federal_agencies_in_the_United_States "List of federal agencies in the United States").[[253]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-271)
triples.statement: The president appoints Cabinet members and other officials, subject to Senate approval, to administer and enforce federal law and policy.

triples.sentence: There, votes are officially cast by individual electors selected by [their state legislature](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_legislature_(United_States) "State legislature (United States)").[[254]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-272)
triples.statement: In the Electoral College, votes are officially cast by individual electors chosen by their state legislature.

triples.sentence: The next and highest court in the system is the Supreme Court of the United States.[[255]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FedJud-274)
triples.statement: The highest court in the U.S. judicial system is the Supreme Court.

triples.sentence: The U.S. Supreme Court interprets laws and [overturns those it finds unconstitutional](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Judicial_review "Judicial review").[[255]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FedJud-274)
triples.statement: The U.S. Supreme Court has the power to interpret laws and overturn those it deems unconstitutional.

triples.sentence: On average, the Supreme Court receives about 7,000 appeals petitions for [writs of certiorari](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Writs_of_certiorari "Writs of certiorari") each year, but only grants about 80.[[256]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-275)
triples.statement: The Supreme Court receives about 7,000 petitions for writs of certiorari annually but typically grants only about 80.

triples.sentence: As with all other federal judges, the members are appointed for life by the sitting president with Senate approval when a vacancy becomes available.[[257]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-276)
triples.statement: Like all federal judges, Supreme Court justices are appointed for life by the president with Senate approval when a vacancy occurs.

section_body:
Main articles: [U.S. state](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.S._state "U.S. state"), [County (United States)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/County_(United_States) "County (United States)"), [Indian country](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_country "Indian country"), and [Territories of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Territories_of_the_United_States "Territories of the United States")

Further information: [List of states and territories of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_states_and_territories_of_the_United_States "List of states and territories of the United States"), [List of federally recognized tribes by state](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_federally_recognized_tribes_by_state "List of federally recognized tribes by state"), and [Federally recognized tribe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federally_recognized_tribe "Federally recognized tribe")

[![Image 44: Territories of the United States.](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/United_States_%28%2Boverseas%29%2C_administrative_divisions_-_en_-_colored_%28zoom%29.svg/330px-United_States_%28%2Boverseas%29%2C_administrative_divisions_-_en_-_colored_%28zoom%29.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:United_States_(%2Boverseas),_administrative_divisions_-_en_-_colored_(zoom).svg)

[Territories of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Territories_of_the_United_States "Territories of the United States") include [American Samoa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Samoa "American Samoa"), [Guam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guam "Guam"), the [Northern Mariana Islands](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northern_Mariana_Islands "Northern Mariana Islands"), [Puerto Rico](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Puerto_Rico "Puerto Rico"), and the [U.S. Virgin Islands](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Virgin_Islands "United States Virgin Islands").

In the [U.S. federal system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federalism_in_the_United_States "Federalism in the United States"), sovereign powers are shared between three levels of government specified in the Constitution: the national government, the states, and Indian tribes.[[259]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-3Sovereigns-278)[[260]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FelixSCohen-279) The U.S. also asserts sovereignty over five permanently inhabited territories: [American Samoa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Samoa "American Samoa"), [Guam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guam "Guam"), the [Northern Mariana Islands](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northern_Mariana_Islands "Northern Mariana Islands"), [Puerto Rico](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Puerto_Rico "Puerto Rico"), and the [U.S. Virgin Islands](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Virgin_Islands "United States Virgin Islands").[[19]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-HRI-2012-28)

Residents of the 50 states are governed by their elected state government, under [state constitutions compatible with the national constitution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_constitutions_in_the_United_States "State constitutions in the United States"), and by elected [local governments](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Local_government_in_the_United_States "Local government in the United States") that are administrative divisions of a state.[[261]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-280) States are subdivided into counties or county equivalents, and (except for Hawaii) [further divided into municipalities](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Local_government_in_the_United_States "Local government in the United States"), each administered by elected representatives. The District of Columbia is [a federal district](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_district_of_the_United_States "Federal district of the United States") containing the U.S. capital, [Washington, D.C.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington,_D.C. "Washington, D.C.")[[262]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-281) The federal district is an administrative division of the federal government.[[263]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-282)

[![Image 45](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Indian_Reservations.png/250px-Indian_Reservations.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Indian_Reservations.png)

Map of [326 Indian reservations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Indian_reservations_in_the_United_States "List of Indian reservations in the United States") in the United States; 231 recognized [Alaska Native tribes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Alaska_Native_tribal_entities "List of Alaska Native tribal entities") are not shown.

Indian country is made up of 574 [federally recognized tribes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federally_recognized_tribe "Federally recognized tribe") and [326 Indian reservations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Indian_reservations_in_the_United_States "List of Indian reservations in the United States"). They hold a government-to-government relationship with the U.S. federal government in Washington and are legally defined as [domestic dependent nations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domestic_dependent_nations "Domestic dependent nations") with [inherent tribal sovereignty rights](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tribal_sovereignty_in_the_United_States "Tribal sovereignty in the United States").[[260]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FelixSCohen-279)[[259]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-3Sovereigns-278)[[264]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-283)[[265]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-www.justice.gov-2017-284)

In addition to the five major territories, the U.S. also asserts sovereignty over the [United States Minor Outlying Islands](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Minor_Outlying_Islands "United States Minor Outlying Islands") in the [Pacific Ocean](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Ocean "Pacific Ocean") and the [Caribbean](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Caribbean "Caribbean").[[19]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-HRI-2012-28) The seven undisputed islands without permanent populations are [Baker Island](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baker_Island "Baker Island"), [Howland Island](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Howland_Island "Howland Island"), [Jarvis Island](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jarvis_Island "Jarvis Island"), [Johnston Atoll](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Johnston_Atoll "Johnston Atoll"), [Kingman Reef](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kingman_Reef "Kingman Reef"), [Midway Atoll](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Midway_Atoll "Midway Atoll"), and [Palmyra Atoll](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Palmyra_Atoll "Palmyra Atoll"). U.S. sovereignty over the unpopulated [Bajo Nuevo Bank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bajo_Nuevo_Bank "Bajo Nuevo Bank"), [Navassa Island](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Navassa_Island "Navassa Island"), [Serranilla Bank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Serranilla_Bank "Serranilla Bank"), and [Wake Island](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wake_Island "Wake Island") is disputed.[[19]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-HRI-2012-28)

![Image 46](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Map_of_USA_with_state_and_territory_names_2.png/960px-Map_of_USA_with_state_and_territory_names_2.png)[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Map_of_USA_with_state_and_territory_names_2.png)

triples.statement: The U.S. asserts sovereignty over five permanently inhabited territories: American Samoa, Guam, the Northern Mariana Islands, Puerto Rico, and the U.S. Virgin Islands.

"Washington, D.C.")[[262]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-281)
triples.statement: The District of Columbia is a federal district containing the U.S. capital, Washington, D.C.

triples.statement: The federal district is an administrative division of the federal government.

triples.statement: In addition to the five major territories, the U.S. also asserts sovereignty over the United States Minor Outlying Islands in the Pacific Ocean and the Caribbean.

triples.sentence: U.S. sovereignty over the unpopulated [Bajo Nuevo Bank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bajo_Nuevo_Bank "Bajo Nuevo Bank"), [Navassa Island](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Navassa_Island "Navassa Island"), [Serranilla Bank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Serranilla_Bank "Serranilla Bank"), and [Wake Island](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wake_Island "Wake Island") is disputed.[[19]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-HRI-2012-28)

section_body:
Main articles: [Foreign relations of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_the_United_States "Foreign relations of the United States") and [Foreign policy of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foreign_policy_of_the_United_States "Foreign policy of the United States")

[![Image 48: see caption](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Midtown_Manhattan_Skyline_004_%28cropped%29.jpg/250px-Midtown_Manhattan_Skyline_004_%28cropped%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Midtown_Manhattan_Skyline_004_(cropped).jpg)

The [United Nations headquarters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Headquarters_of_the_United_Nations "Headquarters of the United Nations") has been situated along the [East River](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/East_River "East River") in [Midtown Manhattan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Midtown_Manhattan "Midtown Manhattan") since 1952; in 1945, the United States was a [founding member of the UN](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Founding_member_of_the_United_Nations "Founding member of the United Nations").

The United States has an established structure of foreign relations, with the world's [second-largest diplomatic corps](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_diplomatic_missions "List of countries by number of diplomatic missions") as of 2024[[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=United_States&action=edit). It is a [permanent member of the United Nations Security Council](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Permanent_members_of_the_United_Nations_Security_Council "Permanent members of the United Nations Security Council")[[269]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-288) and home to the [United Nations headquarters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Headquarters_of_the_United_Nations "Headquarters of the United Nations").[[270]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-289) The United States is a member of the [G7](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/G7 "G7"),[[271]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-290)[G20](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/G20 "G20"),[[272]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-291) and [OECD](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OECD "OECD") intergovernmental organizations.[[273]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-292)[Almost all countries have embassies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_diplomatic_missions_in_the_United_States "List of diplomatic missions in the United States") and many have [consulates](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consul_(representative) "Consul (representative)") (official representatives) in the country. Likewise, nearly all countries host formal [diplomatic missions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diplomatic_mission "Diplomatic mission") with the United States, except [Iran](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iran%E2%80%93United_States_relations "Iran–United States relations"),[[274]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-293)[North Korea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_Korea%E2%80%93United_States_relations "North Korea–United States relations"),[[275]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-294) and [Bhutan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Bhutan#Other_countries "Foreign relations of Bhutan").[[276]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-295) Though [Taiwan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Taiwan%E2%80%93United_States_relations "Taiwan–United States relations") does not have formal diplomatic relations with the U.S., it maintains close unofficial relations.[[277]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-296) The United States regularly [supplies Taiwan with military equipment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Six_Assurances "Six Assurances") to deter potential Chinese aggression.[[278]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-297) Its geopolitical attention also turned to the [Indo-Pacific](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indo-Pacific "Indo-Pacific") when the United States joined the [Quadrilateral Security Dialogue](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quadrilateral_Security_Dialogue "Quadrilateral Security Dialogue") with Australia, India, and Japan.[[279]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-kobara-298)

The United States has a "[Special Relationship](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special_Relationship "Special Relationship")" [with the United Kingdom](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Kingdom%E2%80%93United_States_relations "United Kingdom–United States relations")[[280]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-299) and strong ties [with Canada](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canada%E2%80%93United_States_relations "Canada–United States relations"),[[281]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-300)[Australia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australia%E2%80%93United_States_relations "Australia–United States relations"),[[282]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-301)[New Zealand](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Zealand%E2%80%93United_States_relations "New Zealand–United States relations"),[[283]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-302)[the Philippines](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philippines%E2%80%93United_States_relations "Philippines–United States relations"),[[284]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-303)[Japan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Japan%E2%80%93United_States_relations "Japan–United States relations"),[[285]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-304)[South Korea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Korea%E2%80%93United_States_relations "South Korea–United States relations"),[[286]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-305)[Israel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Israel%E2%80%93United_States_relations "Israel–United States relations"),[[287]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-306) and several [European Union countries](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Member_state_of_the_European_Union "Member state of the European Union") such as [France](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/France%E2%80%93United_States_relations "France–United States relations"), [Italy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Italy%E2%80%93United_States_relations "Italy–United States relations"), [Germany](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Germany%E2%80%93United_States_relations "Germany–United States relations"), [Spain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spain%E2%80%93United_States_relations "Spain–United States relations"), and [Poland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Poland%E2%80%93United_States_relations "Poland–United States relations").[[288]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-307) The U.S. works closely with its [NATO](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NATO "NATO") allies on military and [national security](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_security "National security") issues, and with countries in the Americas through the [Organization of American States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Organization_of_American_States "Organization of American States") and the [United States–Mexico–Canada Free Trade Agreement](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States%E2%80%93Mexico%E2%80%93Canada_Agreement "United States–Mexico–Canada Agreement"). The U.S. exercises full international defense authority and responsibility for [Micronesia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federated_States_of_Micronesia "Federated States of Micronesia"), the [Marshall Islands](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marshall_Islands "Marshall Islands"), and [Palau](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Palau "Palau") through the [Compact of Free Association](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compact_of_Free_Association "Compact of Free Association").[[255]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FedJud-274) It has increasingly conducted strategic cooperation [with India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India%E2%80%93United_States_relations "India–United States relations"),[[289]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-308) while [its ties with China](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China%E2%80%93United_States_relations "China–United States relations") have steadily deteriorated.[[290]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-309)[[291]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-310)

Beginning in 2014, the U.S. had become [a key ally of Ukraine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ukraine%E2%80%93United_States_relations "Ukraine–United States relations").[[292]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-311)[[293]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-312) After [Donald Trump](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump "Donald Trump") was elected U.S. president in 2024, he sought to negotiate an end to the [Russo-Ukrainian War](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russo-Ukrainian_War "Russo-Ukrainian War"). He paused all military aid to Ukraine in March 2025,[[294]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-313) although the aid resumed later.[[295]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-314) Trump also ended U.S. intelligence sharing with the country,[[296]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-:5-315) but this too was eventually restored.[[297]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-316)

triples.sentence: Though [Taiwan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Taiwan%E2%80%93United_States_relations "Taiwan–United States relations") does not have formal diplomatic relations with the U.S., it maintains close unofficial relations.[[277]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-296)
triples.statement: Taiwan maintains close unofficial relations with the U.S., despite not having formal diplomatic relations.

triples.sentence: The United States regularly [supplies Taiwan with military equipment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Six_Assurances "Six Assurances") to deter potential Chinese aggression.[[278]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-297)
triples.statement: The United States regularly supplies Taiwan with military equipment to deter potential aggression from China.

triples.sentence: Its geopolitical attention also turned to the [Indo-Pacific](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indo-Pacific "Indo-Pacific") when the United States joined the [Quadrilateral Security Dialogue](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quadrilateral_Security_Dialogue "Quadrilateral Security Dialogue") with Australia, India, and Japan.[[279]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-kobara-298)
triples.statement: The United States' geopolitical focus turned to the Indo-Pacific when it joined the Quadrilateral Security Dialogue with Australia, India, and Japan.

triples.sentence: The U.S. exercises full international defense authority and responsibility for [Micronesia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federated_States_of_Micronesia "Federated States of Micronesia"), the [Marshall Islands](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marshall_Islands "Marshall Islands"), and [Palau](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Palau "Palau") through the [Compact of Free Association](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compact_of_Free_Association "Compact of Free Association").[[255]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FedJud-274)
triples.statement: Through the Compact of Free Association, the U.S. has full international defense authority and responsibility for Micronesia, the Marshall Islands, and Palau.

triples.sentence: Beginning in 2014, the U.S. had become [a key ally of Ukraine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ukraine%E2%80%93United_States_relations "Ukraine–United States relations").[[292]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-311)[[293]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-312)
triples.statement: Starting in 2014, the U.S. became a key ally of Ukraine.

triples.sentence: He paused all military aid to Ukraine in March 2025,[[294]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-313) although the aid resumed later.[[295]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-314)
triples.statement: In March 2025, he paused all military aid to Ukraine, though it was later resumed.

section_body:
Main article: [United States Armed Forces](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Armed_Forces "United States Armed Forces")

[![Image 49](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/The_Pentagon%2C_Headquarters_of_the_US_Department_of_Defense_%28cropped2%29.jpg/250px-The_Pentagon%2C_Headquarters_of_the_US_Department_of_Defense_%28cropped2%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:The_Pentagon,_Headquarters_of_the_US_Department_of_Defense_(cropped2).jpg)

[The Pentagon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Pentagon "The Pentagon"), the headquarters of the [U.S. Department of Defense](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Defense "United States Department of Defense") in [Arlington County, Virginia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arlington_County,_Virginia "Arlington County, Virginia"), is one of the world's largest office buildings with over 6.5 million square feet (600,000 m 2) of [floor space](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Floor_space "Floor space").

The president is the [commander-in-chief](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commander-in-Chief_of_the_United_States "Commander-in-Chief of the United States") of the United States Armed Forces and appoints its leaders, the [secretary of defense](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_Defense "United States Secretary of Defense") and the [Joint Chiefs of Staff](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joint_Chiefs_of_Staff "Joint Chiefs of Staff"). The [Department of Defense](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Defense "United States Department of Defense"), headquartered at [the Pentagon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Pentagon "The Pentagon") near Washington, D.C., administers five of the six service branches, which are made up of the [U.S. Army](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Army "United States Army"), [Marine Corps](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Marine_Corps "United States Marine Corps"), [Navy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Navy "United States Navy"), [Air Force](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Air_Force "United States Air Force"), and [Space Force](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Space_Force "United States Space Force").[[298]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-317) The [Coast Guard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Coast_Guard "United States Coast Guard") is administered by the [Department of Homeland Security](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Homeland_Security "United States Department of Homeland Security") in peacetime and can be transferred to the [Department of the Navy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Department_of_the_Navy "United States Department of the Navy") in wartime.[[299]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-318)

The United States [spent $997 billion on its military](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Military_budget_of_the_United_States "Military budget of the United States") in 2024, which is by far the [largest amount of any country](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_with_highest_military_expenditures "List of countries with highest military expenditures"), making up 37% of global military spending and accounting for 3.4% of the country's GDP._**[[300]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United\_States#cite\_note-SIPRI-20202-319)**_ The [U.S. possesses](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nuclear_weapons_of_the_United_States "Nuclear weapons of the United States") 42% of the world's nuclear weapons—the second-largest stockpile after [that of Russia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russia_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction "Russia and weapons of mass destruction").[[301]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Stockholm_International_Peace_Research_Institute-2024-320) The U.S. military is widely regarded as the most powerful and advanced in the world.[[302]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-321)[[303]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-322)

The United States has the [third-largest combined armed forces](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_military_and_paramilitary_personnel "List of countries by number of military and paramilitary personnel") in the world, behind the [Chinese People's Liberation Army](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/People%27s_Liberation_Army "People's Liberation Army") and [Indian Armed Forces](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Armed_Forces "Indian Armed Forces").[[304]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-323) The U.S. military operates about 800 bases and facilities abroad,[[305]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-324) and maintains [deployments greater than 100 active duty personnel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_military_deployments "United States military deployments") in 25 foreign countries.[[306]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-325) The United States has engaged in over 400 military interventions since its founding in 1776, with over half of these occurring between 1950 and 2019 and 25% occurring in the post-Cold War era.[[307]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-326)

[State defense forces](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_defense_forces "State defense forces") (SDFs) are military units that operate under the sole authority of a state government. SDFs are authorized by state and federal law but are under the command of [the state's governor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Governor_(United_States) "Governor (United States)").[[308]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-327)[[309]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-328)[[310]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-329) By contrast, a state's [National Guard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Guard_(United_States) "National Guard (United States)") units are under the dual control of [state](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_governments_of_the_United_States "State governments of the United States") and [federal governments](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_government_of_the_United_States "Federal government of the United States"); such units can also become federalized entities, but SDFs cannot be federalized.[[311]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-330) A state's National Guard personnel can be federalized by the president under the [National Defense Act Amendments of 1933](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Defense_Act_of_1916#National_Defense_Act_Amendments_of_1933 "National Defense Act of 1916"), which created the Guard and provides for the integration of [Army National Guard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Army_National_Guard "Army National Guard")&[Air National Guard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Air_National_Guard "Air National Guard") units and personnel into the U.S. Army and (since 1947) the U.S. Air Force.[[312]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-331)

triples.sentence: The [Department of Defense](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Defense "United States Department of Defense"), headquartered at [the Pentagon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Pentagon "The Pentagon") near Washington, D.C., administers five of the six service branches, which are made up of the [U.S. Army](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Army "United States Army"), [Marine Corps](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Marine_Corps "United States Marine Corps"), [Navy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Navy "United States Navy"), [Air Force](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Air_Force "United States Air Force"), and [Space Force](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Space_Force "United States Space Force").[[298]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-317)
triples.statement: The Department of Defense, headquartered at the Pentagon, administers five of the six service branches: the U.S. Army, Marine Corps, Navy, Air Force, and Space Force.

triples.sentence: The [Coast Guard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Coast_Guard "United States Coast Guard") is administered by the [Department of Homeland Security](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Homeland_Security "United States Department of Homeland Security") in peacetime and can be transferred to the [Department of the Navy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Department_of_the_Navy "United States Department of the Navy") in wartime.[[299]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-318)
triples.statement: The Coast Guard is administered by the Department of Homeland Security in peacetime and can be transferred to the Department of the Navy in wartime.

triples.sentence: The [U.S. possesses](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nuclear_weapons_of_the_United_States "Nuclear weapons of the United States") 42% of the world's nuclear weapons—the second-largest stockpile after [that of Russia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russia_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction "Russia and weapons of mass destruction").[[301]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Stockholm_International_Peace_Research_Institute-2024-320)
triples.statement: The U.S. possesses 42% of the world's nuclear weapons, the second-largest stockpile after Russia.

triples.sentence: The U.S. military is widely regarded as the most powerful and advanced in the world.[[302]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-321)[[303]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-322)
triples.statement: The U.S. military is widely regarded as the most powerful and advanced in the world.

triples.sentence: The U.S. military operates about 800 bases and facilities abroad,[[305]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-324) and maintains [deployments greater than 100 active duty personnel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_military_deployments "United States military deployments") in 25 foreign countries.[[306]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-325)
triples.statement: The U.S. military operates about 800 bases and facilities abroad and maintains deployments of over 100 active duty personnel in 25 foreign countries.

triples.sentence: The United States has engaged in over 400 military interventions since its founding in 1776, with over half of these occurring between 1950 and 2019 and 25% occurring in the post-Cold War era.[[307]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-326)
triples.statement: Since its founding in 1776, the United States has engaged in over 400 military interventions, with more than half taking place between 1950 and 2019 and a quarter in the post-Cold War era.

triples.sentence: SDFs are authorized by state and federal law but are under the command of [the state's governor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Governor_(United_States) "Governor (United States)").[[308]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-327)[[309]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-328)[[310]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-329)
triples.statement: SDFs are authorized by state and federal law but are under the command of the state's governor.

triples.sentence: By contrast, a state's [National Guard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Guard_(United_States) "National Guard (United States)") units are under the dual control of [state](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_governments_of_the_United_States "State governments of the United States") and [federal governments](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_government_of_the_United_States "Federal government of the United States"); such units can also become federalized entities, but SDFs cannot be federalized.[[311]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-330)
triples.statement: In contrast to State Defense Forces (SDFs), which cannot be federalized, a state's National Guard units are under the dual control of state and federal governments and can be federalized.

triples.sentence: A state's National Guard personnel can be federalized by the president under the [National Defense Act Amendments of 1933](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Defense_Act_of_1916#National_Defense_Act_Amendments_of_1933 "National Defense Act of 1916"), which created the Guard and provides for the integration of [Army National Guard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Army_National_Guard "Army National Guard")&[Air National Guard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Air_National_Guard "Air National Guard") units and personnel into the U.S. Army and (since 1947) the U.S. Air Force.[[312]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-331)
triples.statement: Under the National Defense Act Amendments of 1933, the president can federalize a state's National Guard personnel, integrating Army and Air National Guard units into the U.S. Army and U.S. Air Force.

section_body:
Main articles: [Law of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Law_of_the_United_States "Law of the United States"), [Law enforcement in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Law_enforcement_in_the_United_States "Law enforcement in the United States"), and [Crime in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crime_in_the_United_States "Crime in the United States")

[![Image 50](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/FBI_Headquarters_-_J._Edgar_Hoover_Building_%2853840035941%29.jpg/250px-FBI_Headquarters_-_J._Edgar_Hoover_Building_%2853840035941%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:FBI_Headquarters_-_J._Edgar_Hoover_Building_(53840035941).jpg)

[J. Edgar Hoover Building](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J._Edgar_Hoover_Building "J. Edgar Hoover Building"), the headquarters of the [Federal Bureau of Investigation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation "Federal Bureau of Investigation") (FBI), in [Washington, D.C.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington,_D.C. "Washington, D.C.")

There are about 18,000 U.S. police agencies from local to national level in the United States.[[313]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-332) Law in the United States is mainly enforced by local police departments and [sheriff departments](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sheriffs_in_the_United_States "Sheriffs in the United States") in their municipal or county jurisdictions. [The state police](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_police_(United_States) "State police (United States)") departments [have authority in their respective state](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Police_power_(United_States_constitutional_law) "Police power (United States constitutional law)"), and [federal agencies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_law_enforcement_in_the_United_States "Federal law enforcement in the United States") such as the [Federal Bureau of Investigation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation "Federal Bureau of Investigation") (FBI) and the [U.S. Marshals Service](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Marshals_Service "United States Marshals Service") have national jurisdiction and specialized duties, such as protecting [civil rights](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Civil_rights "Civil rights"), [national security](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_security_of_the_United_States "National security of the United States"), enforcing [U.S. federal courts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.S._federal_courts "U.S. federal courts")' rulings and federal laws, and interstate criminal activity.[[314]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-333)[State courts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_court_(United_States) "State court (United States)") conduct almost all civil and criminal trials,[[315]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-334) while federal courts [adjudicate the much smaller number of civil and criminal cases that relate to federal law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subject-matter_jurisdiction "Subject-matter jurisdiction").[[316]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-335)

There is no unified "criminal justice system" in the United States. The [American prison system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Incarceration_in_the_United_States "Incarceration in the United States") is largely heterogenous, with thousands of relatively independent systems operating across federal, state, local, and tribal levels. In 2025, "these systems hold [nearly 2 million people](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_incarceration_rate "United States incarceration rate") in 1,566 state prisons, 98 federal prisons, 3,116 local jails, 1,277 juvenile correctional facilities, 133 immigration detention facilities, and 80 Indian country jails, as well as in military prisons, civil commitment centers, state psychiatric hospitals, and prisons in the U.S. territories."[[317]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Sawyer-2025-336)

Despite disparate systems of confinement, four main institutions dominate: [federal prisons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_United_States_federal_prisons "List of United States federal prisons"), [state prisons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lists_of_United_States_state_prisons "Lists of United States state prisons"), local jails, and [juvenile correctional facilities](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_juvenile_justice_system "American juvenile justice system").[[318]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-National_Academies_Press-2014-337) Federal prisons are run by the [Federal Bureau of Prisons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Bureau_of_Prisons "Federal Bureau of Prisons") and hold pretrial detainees as well as people who have been convicted of federal crimes.[[318]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-National_Academies_Press-2014-337) State prisons, run by the department of corrections of each state, hold people sentenced and serving prison time (usually longer than one year) for felony offenses.[[318]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-National_Academies_Press-2014-337) Local jails are county or municipal facilities that incarcerate defendants prior to trial; they also hold those serving short sentences (typically under a year).[[318]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-National_Academies_Press-2014-337) Juvenile correctional facilities are operated by local or state governments and serve as longer-term placements for any [minor adjudicated as delinquent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Juvenile_delinquency "Juvenile delinquency") and ordered by a judge to be confined.[[319]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-338)

In January 2023, the United States had the [sixth-highest per capita incarceration rate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_incarceration_rate "List of countries by incarceration rate") in the world—531 people per 100,000 inhabitants—and the largest prison and jail population in the world, with more than 1.9 million people incarcerated.[[317]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Sawyer-2025-336)[[320]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-339)[[321]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-WorldPrisonBrief-340) An analysis of the [World Health Organization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Health_Organization "World Health Organization") Mortality Database from 2010 showed U.S. homicide rates "were 7 times higher than in other high-income countries, driven by [a gun homicide rate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gun_deaths_in_the_United_States "Gun deaths in the United States") that was 25 times higher".[[322]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-341)

triples.sentence: There are about 18,000 U.S. police agencies from local to national level in the United States.[[313]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-332)
triples.statement: The United States has approximately 18,000 police agencies, ranging from local to national levels.

triples.sentence: [The state police](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_police_(United_States) "State police (United States)") departments [have authority in their respective state](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Police_power_(United_States_constitutional_law) "Police power (United States constitutional law)"), and [federal agencies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_law_enforcement_in_the_United_States "Federal law enforcement in the United States") such as the [Federal Bureau of Investigation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation "Federal Bureau of Investigation") (FBI) and the [U.S. Marshals Service](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Marshals_Service "United States Marshals Service") have national jurisdiction and specialized duties, such as protecting [civil rights](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Civil_rights "Civil rights"), [national security](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_security_of_the_United_States "National security of the United States"), enforcing [U.S. federal courts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.S._federal_courts "U.S. federal courts")' rulings and federal laws, and interstate criminal activity.[[314]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-333)
triples.statement: State police departments have authority within their respective states, while federal agencies like the FBI and U.S. Marshals Service have national jurisdiction for specialized duties including protecting civil rights, national security, and enforcing federal laws.

triples.sentence: In 2025, "these systems hold [nearly 2 million people](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_incarceration_rate "United States incarceration rate") in 1,566 state prisons, 98 federal prisons, 3,116 local jails, 1,277 juvenile correctional facilities, 133 immigration detention facilities, and 80 Indian country jails, as well as in military prisons, civil commitment centers, state psychiatric hospitals, and prisons in the U.S. territories."[[317]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Sawyer-2025-336)
triples.statement: In 2025, U.S. correctional systems hold nearly 2 million people across a wide range of facilities, including 1,566 state prisons, 98 federal prisons, 3,116 local jails, and numerous other types of detention centers.

triples.sentence: Despite disparate systems of confinement, four main institutions dominate: [federal prisons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_United_States_federal_prisons "List of United States federal prisons"), [state prisons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lists_of_United_States_state_prisons "Lists of United States state prisons"), local jails, and [juvenile correctional facilities](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_juvenile_justice_system "American juvenile justice system").[[318]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-National_Academies_Press-2014-337)
triples.statement: Four main types of institutions dominate the U.S. confinement systems: federal prisons, state prisons, local jails, and juvenile correctional facilities.

triples.sentence: Federal prisons are run by the [Federal Bureau of Prisons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Bureau_of_Prisons "Federal Bureau of Prisons") and hold pretrial detainees as well as people who have been convicted of federal crimes.[[318]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-National_Academies_Press-2014-337)
triples.statement: Federal prisons, managed by the Federal Bureau of Prisons, house both pretrial detainees and individuals convicted of federal crimes.

triples.sentence: State prisons, run by the department of corrections of each state, hold people sentenced and serving prison time (usually longer than one year) for felony offenses.[[318]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-National_Academies_Press-2014-337)
triples.statement: State prisons, operated by each state's department of corrections, hold individuals serving sentences (typically over a year) for felony offenses.

triples.sentence: Local jails are county or municipal facilities that incarcerate defendants prior to trial; they also hold those serving short sentences (typically under a year).[[318]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-National_Academies_Press-2014-337)
triples.statement: Local jails, which are county or municipal facilities, hold defendants before trial and also those serving short sentences, usually less than a year.

triples.sentence: Juvenile correctional facilities are operated by local or state governments and serve as longer-term placements for any [minor adjudicated as delinquent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Juvenile_delinquency "Juvenile delinquency") and ordered by a judge to be confined.[[319]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-338)
triples.statement: Juvenile correctional facilities, run by local or state governments, are used for longer-term placements for minors who have been judged delinquent and ordered to be confined.

triples.sentence: In January 2023, the United States had the [sixth-highest per capita incarceration rate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_incarceration_rate "List of countries by incarceration rate") in the world—531 people per 100,000 inhabitants—and the largest prison and jail population in the world, with more than 1.9 million people incarcerated.[[317]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Sawyer-2025-336)[[320]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-339)[[321]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-WorldPrisonBrief-340)
triples.statement: As of January 2023, the U.S. had the world's sixth-highest per capita incarceration rate (531 per 100,000 inhabitants) and the largest total incarcerated population, with over 1.9 million people.

section_body:
Main article: [Economy of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economy_of_the_United_States "Economy of the United States")

[![Image 51: see caption](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/US_one_dollar_bill%2C_obverse%2C_series_2009.jpg/250px-US_one_dollar_bill%2C_obverse%2C_series_2009.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:US_one_dollar_bill,_obverse,_series_2009.jpg)

The [U.S. dollar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_dollar "United States dollar") is the most-used currency [in international transactions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_use_of_the_U.S._dollar "International use of the U.S. dollar") and the world's foremost [reserve currency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reserve_currency "Reserve currency").
