The U.S. has a highly developed [mixed economy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mixed_economy "Mixed economy")[[323]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-342) that has been the world's largest nominally [since about 1890](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_largest_historical_GDP "List of countries by largest historical GDP").[[324]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-343) Its 2024 [gross domestic product](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gross_domestic_product "Gross domestic product") (GDP)[[e]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-PPP-20) of more than $29 trillion[[325]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-344) constituted over 25% of nominal [global economic output](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gross_world_product "Gross world product"), or 15% at [purchasing power parity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity "Purchasing power parity") (PPP). From 1983 to 2008, U.S. real compounded annual GDP growth was 3.3%, compared to a 2.3% weighted average for the rest of the [G7](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/G7 "G7").[[326]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Hagopian-345) The country ranks [first in the world by nominal GDP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal) "List of countries by GDP (nominal)"),[[327]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-346)[second when adjusted for purchasing power parities](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP) "List of countries by GDP (PPP)") (PPP),[[15]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-IMFWEO.US-19) and [ninth by PPP-adjusted GDP per capita](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)_per_capita "List of countries by GDP (PPP) per capita").[[15]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-IMFWEO.US-19) In February 2024, the total [U.S. federal government debt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_debt_of_the_United_States "National debt of the United States") was $34.4 trillion.[[328]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-347)

[![Image 52](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/View_of_Empire_State_Building_from_Rockefeller_Center_New_York_City_dllu_%28cropped%29.jpg/250px-View_of_Empire_State_Building_from_Rockefeller_Center_New_York_City_dllu_%28cropped%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:View_of_Empire_State_Building_from_Rockefeller_Center_New_York_City_dllu_(cropped).jpg)

[New York City](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_City "New York City") is the world's principal [financial center](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Financial_center "Financial center"), and [its metropolitan area](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_metropolitan_area "New York metropolitan area") is the world's [largest metropolitan economy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_cities_by_GDP "List of cities by GDP").

Of the world's [500 largest companies by revenue](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fortune_Global_500 "Fortune Global 500"), [138 were headquartered in the U.S.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_largest_companies_in_the_United_States_by_revenue "List of largest companies in the United States by revenue") in 2025,[[329]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Fortune-2025-348) the highest number of any country.[[330]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-349) The [U.S. dollar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_dollar "United States dollar") is the currency most used [in international transactions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_use_of_the_U.S._dollar "International use of the U.S. dollar") and the world's foremost [reserve currency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reserve_currency "Reserve currency"), backed by the country's dominant economy, [its military](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Armed_Forces "United States Armed Forces"), the [petrodollar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Petrodollar "Petrodollar") system, its large [U.S. treasuries market](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.S._Treasury "U.S. Treasury"), and its linked [eurodollar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eurodollar "Eurodollar").[[331]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-federalreserve.gov-350)[Several countries use it as their official currency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_dollar#Countries_that_use_US_dollar "United States dollar"), and in others it is the [_de facto_ currency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/De_facto_currency "De facto currency").[[332]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Benjamin_J._Cohen_2006,_p._17-351)[[333]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-352) The U.S. has [free trade agreements](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Free_trade_agreements "Free trade agreements") with [several countries](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Free_trade_agreements_of_the_United_States "Free trade agreements of the United States"), including the [USMCA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States%E2%80%93Mexico%E2%80%93Canada_Agreement "United States–Mexico–Canada Agreement").[[334]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-353) Although the United States has reached a [post-industrial level of economic development](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Post-industrial_economy "Post-industrial economy")[[335]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Collins-2023-354) and is often described as having a [service economy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Service_economy "Service economy"),[[335]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Collins-2023-354)[[336]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Econ-355) it remains a major industrial power;[[337]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-356) in 2024, the [U.S. manufacturing sector](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.S._manufacturing_sector "U.S. manufacturing sector") was the world's [second-largest by value output](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_manufacturing_output "List of countries by manufacturing output") after [China's](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manufacturing_in_China "Manufacturing in China").[[338]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-357)

[![Image 53](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Gaming-Wall-Street_BTS_Prodigium-266.jpg/250px-Gaming-Wall-Street_BTS_Prodigium-266.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Gaming-Wall-Street_BTS_Prodigium-266.jpg)

The [New York Stock Exchange](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_Stock_Exchange "New York Stock Exchange") on [Wall Street](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wall_Street "Wall Street"), the world's [largest stock exchange by market capitalization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_stock_exchanges#Major_stock_exchanges "List of stock exchanges")[[339]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-NYSEhighestcap-358)

[New York City](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_City "New York City") is the world's principal [financial center](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Financial_center "Financial center"),[[340]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-359)[[341]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-NYCFintechAndFinancialCapitalWorld-360) and [its metropolitan area](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_metropolitan_area "New York metropolitan area") is the world's [largest metropolitan economy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_cities_by_GDP "List of cities by GDP").[[342]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-NYCEpicenterUSMetroEconomy-361) The [New York Stock Exchange](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_Stock_Exchange "New York Stock Exchange") and [Nasdaq](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nasdaq "Nasdaq"), both located in New York City, are the world's two [largest stock exchanges](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_stock_exchanges "List of stock exchanges") by [market capitalization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Market_capitalization "Market capitalization") and [trade volume](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trade_volume "Trade volume").[[343]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-362)[[344]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-sfc.hk-363) The United States is at the forefront of [technological advancement](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_the_United_States "Science and technology in the United States") and [innovation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Innovation "Innovation") in many economic fields, especially in [artificial intelligence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence "Artificial intelligence"); [electronics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electronics "Electronics") and [computers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer "Computer"); [pharmaceuticals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pharmaceuticals "Pharmaceuticals"); and medical, [aerospace](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aerospace "Aerospace") and [military equipment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Military_equipment "Military equipment").[[345]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-CIA-2018-364) The country's economy is fueled by abundant [natural resources](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_resource "Natural resource"), a well-developed [infrastructure](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infrastructure_policy_of_the_United_States "Infrastructure policy of the United States"), and [high productivity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_labour_productivity "List of countries by labour productivity").[[346]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Wright,_Gavin_2007_p._185-365) The [largest trading partners of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_the_largest_trading_partners_of_the_United_States "List of the largest trading partners of the United States") are the [European Union](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_Union "European Union"), Mexico, Canada, China, Japan, South Korea, the United Kingdom, Vietnam, India, and Taiwan.[[347]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-366) The United States is the world's [largest importer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_imports "List of countries by imports") and [second-largest exporter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_exports "List of countries by exports").[[t]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-369) It is by far the world's [largest exporter of services](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_service_exports "List of countries by service exports").[[350]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-370)

Americans have the highest average [household](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Household_income "Household income")[[351]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-371) and [employee income](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_average_wage "List of countries by average wage") among OECD member states, and the fourth-highest [median household income](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Median_income "Median income") in 2023,[[352]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-372) up from sixth-highest in 2013.[[353]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Household_Income-373) With personal [consumption expenditures](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consumer_spending "Consumer spending") of over $18.5 trillion in 2023,[[354]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-374) the U.S. has a heavily [consumer-driven economy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consumer_economy "Consumer economy") and is the world's [largest consumer market](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_largest_consumer_markets "List of largest consumer markets").[[355]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-375) The U.S. [ranked first in the number of dollar billionaires](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_billionaires "List of countries by number of billionaires") and [millionaires](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_millionaires "List of countries by number of millionaires") in 2023, with 735 billionaires and nearly 22 million millionaires.[[356]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-376)

[Wealth in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wealth_in_the_United_States "Wealth in the United States") is highly concentrated; in 2011, the richest 10% of the adult population owned 72% of the country's household wealth, while the bottom 50% owned just 2%.[[357]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-377)[U.S. wealth inequality](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wealth_inequality_in_the_United_States "Wealth inequality in the United States") increased substantially since the late 1980s,[[358]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Smith-2022-378) and [income inequality in the U.S.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Income_inequality_in_the_United_States "Income inequality in the United States") reached a record high in 2019.[[359]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-379) In 2024, the country had some of the highest wealth and income inequality levels among [OECD](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OECD "OECD") countries.[[360]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-380) Since the 1970s, there has been a decoupling of U.S. wage gains from worker productivity.[[361]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Hopkin-381) In 2016, the top fifth of earners took home more than half of all income,[[362]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-382) giving the U.S. one of the widest income distributions among OECD countries.[[363]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Sme-383)[[361]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Hopkin-381) There were about 771,480 [homeless persons in the U.S.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homelessness_in_the_United_States "Homelessness in the United States") in 2024.[[364]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-384) In 2022, 6.4 million children experienced food insecurity.[[365]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-ers.usda.gov-385)[Feeding America](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feeding_America "Feeding America") estimates that around one in five, or approximately 13 million, [children experience hunger in the U.S.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hunger_in_the_United_States#Children "Hunger in the United States") and do not know where or when they will get their next meal.[[366]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FactsAbout-386) Also in 2022, about 37.9 million people, or 11.5% of the U.S. population, were [living in poverty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Poverty_in_the_United_States "Poverty in the United States").[[367]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-387)

The United States has a smaller [welfare state](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Welfare_state "Welfare state") and redistributes less income through government action than most other [high-income countries](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Bank_high-income_economy "World Bank high-income economy").[[368]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-388)[[369]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-389) It is the only [advanced economy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Advanced_economy "Advanced economy") that does not [guarantee its workers paid vacation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_statutory_minimum_employment_leave_by_country "List of statutory minimum employment leave by country") nationally[[370]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-390) and one of a few countries in the world without federal [paid family leave](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parental_leave_in_the_United_States "Parental leave in the United States") as a legal right.[[371]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-391) The United States has a higher percentage of low-income [workers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Working_class_in_the_United_States "Working class in the United States") than almost any other developed country, largely because of a weak [collective bargaining](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collective_bargaining "Collective bargaining") system and lack of government support for at-risk workers.[[372]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-392)

triples.sentence: The U.S. has a highly developed [mixed economy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mixed_economy "Mixed economy")[[323]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-342) that has been the world's largest nominally [since about 1890](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_largest_historical_GDP "List of countries by largest historical GDP").[[324]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-343)
triples.statement: The U.S. has a highly developed mixed economy and has been the world's largest in nominal terms since about 1890.

triples.sentence: Its 2024 [gross domestic product](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gross_domestic_product "Gross domestic product") (GDP)[[e]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-PPP-20) of more than $29 trillion[[325]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-344) constituted over 25% of nominal [global economic output](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gross_world_product "Gross world product"), or 15% at [purchasing power parity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity "Purchasing power parity") (PPP).
triples.statement: In 2024, the U.S. gross domestic product (GDP) was over $29 trillion, representing more than 25% of the nominal global economic output, or 15% at purchasing power parity (PPP).

triples.sentence: From 1983 to 2008, U.S. real compounded annual GDP growth was 3.3%, compared to a 2.3% weighted average for the rest of the [G7](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/G7 "G7").[[326]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Hagopian-345)
triples.statement: Between 1983 and 2008, the real compounded annual GDP growth of the U.S. was 3.3%, compared to a 2.3% average for the rest of the G7.

triples.sentence: In February 2024, the total [U.S. federal government debt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_debt_of_the_United_States "National debt of the United States") was $34.4 trillion.[[328]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-347)
triples.statement: The total U.S. federal government debt was $34.4 trillion in February 2024.

triples.sentence: Of the world's [500 largest companies by revenue](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fortune_Global_500 "Fortune Global 500"), [138 were headquartered in the U.S.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_largest_companies_in_the_United_States_by_revenue "List of largest companies in the United States by revenue") in 2025,[[329]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Fortune-2025-348) the highest number of any country.[[330]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-349)
triples.statement: In 2025, 138 of the world's 500 largest companies by revenue were headquartered in the U.S., the most of any country.

triples.sentence: The [U.S. dollar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_dollar "United States dollar") is the currency most used [in international transactions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_use_of_the_U.S._dollar "International use of the U.S. dollar") and the world's foremost [reserve currency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reserve_currency "Reserve currency"), backed by the country's dominant economy, [its military](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Armed_Forces "United States Armed Forces"), the [petrodollar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Petrodollar "Petrodollar") system, its large [U.S. treasuries market](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.S._Treasury "U.S. Treasury"), and its linked [eurodollar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eurodollar "Eurodollar").[[331]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-federalreserve.gov-350)
triples.statement: The U.S. dollar is the most used currency for international transactions and the world's primary reserve currency, supported by the nation's economy, military, the petrodollar system, its large treasuries market, and the eurodollar.

triples.sentence: The U.S. has [free trade agreements](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Free_trade_agreements "Free trade agreements") with [several countries](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Free_trade_agreements_of_the_United_States "Free trade agreements of the United States"), including the [USMCA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States%E2%80%93Mexico%E2%80%93Canada_Agreement "United States–Mexico–Canada Agreement").[[334]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-353)
triples.statement: The U.S. has free trade agreements with several countries, including the USMCA.

triples.sentence: Although the United States has reached a [post-industrial level of economic development](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Post-industrial_economy "Post-industrial economy")[[335]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Collins-2023-354) and is often described as having a [service economy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Service_economy "Service economy"),[[335]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Collins-2023-354)[[336]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Econ-355) it remains a major industrial power;[[337]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-356) in 2024, the [U.S. manufacturing sector](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.S._manufacturing_sector "U.S. manufacturing sector") was the world's [second-largest by value output](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_manufacturing_output "List of countries by manufacturing output") after [China's](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manufacturing_in_China "Manufacturing in China").[[338]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-357)
triples.statement: Despite being a post-industrial service economy, the U.S. remains a major industrial power, with its manufacturing sector being the world's second-largest by value output in 2024, after China.

triples.sentence: The [New York Stock Exchange](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_Stock_Exchange "New York Stock Exchange") on [Wall Street](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wall_Street "Wall Street"), the world's [largest stock exchange by market capitalization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_stock_exchanges#Major_stock_exchanges "List of stock exchanges")[[339]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-NYSEhighestcap-358)
triples.statement: The New York Stock Exchange on Wall Street is the world's largest stock exchange by market capitalization.

triples.sentence: [New York City](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_City "New York City") is the world's principal [financial center](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Financial_center "Financial center"),[[340]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-359)[[341]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-NYCFintechAndFinancialCapitalWorld-360) and [its metropolitan area](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_metropolitan_area "New York metropolitan area") is the world's [largest metropolitan economy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_cities_by_GDP "List of cities by GDP").[[342]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-NYCEpicenterUSMetroEconomy-361)
triples.statement: New York City is the world's principal financial center, and its metropolitan area has the largest metropolitan economy in the world.

triples.sentence: The United States is at the forefront of [technological advancement](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_the_United_States "Science and technology in the United States") and [innovation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Innovation "Innovation") in many economic fields, especially in [artificial intelligence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence "Artificial intelligence"); [electronics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electronics "Electronics") and [computers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer "Computer"); [pharmaceuticals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pharmaceuticals "Pharmaceuticals"); and medical, [aerospace](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aerospace "Aerospace") and [military equipment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Military_equipment "Military equipment").[[345]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-CIA-2018-364)
triples.statement: The United States leads in technological advancement and innovation in many economic sectors, including artificial intelligence, electronics, computers, pharmaceuticals, and medical, aerospace, and military equipment.

triples.sentence: The [largest trading partners of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_the_largest_trading_partners_of_the_United_States "List of the largest trading partners of the United States") are the [European Union](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_Union "European Union"), Mexico, Canada, China, Japan, South Korea, the United Kingdom, Vietnam, India, and Taiwan.[[347]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-366)
triples.statement: The largest trading partners of the United States include the European Union, Mexico, Canada, China, Japan, South Korea, the United Kingdom, Vietnam, India, and Taiwan.

triples.sentence: It is by far the world's [largest exporter of services](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_service_exports "List of countries by service exports").[[350]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-370)
triples.statement: The United States is the world's largest exporter of services.

triples.sentence: Americans have the highest average [household](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Household_income "Household income")[[351]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-371) and [employee income](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_average_wage "List of countries by average wage") among OECD member states, and the fourth-highest [median household income](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Median_income "Median income") in 2023,[[352]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-372) up from sixth-highest in 2013.[[353]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Household_Income-373)
triples.statement: Among OECD member states, Americans have the highest average household and employee income, and in 2023 had the fourth-highest median household income, an increase from sixth-highest in 2013.

triples.sentence: The U.S. [ranked first in the number of dollar billionaires](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_billionaires "List of countries by number of billionaires") and [millionaires](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_millionaires "List of countries by number of millionaires") in 2023, with 735 billionaires and nearly 22 million millionaires.[[356]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-376)
triples.statement: In 2023, the U.S. ranked first in the world for the number of billionaires and millionaires, with 735 billionaires and almost 22 million millionaires.

triples.sentence: [Wealth in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wealth_in_the_United_States "Wealth in the United States") is highly concentrated; in 2011, the richest 10% of the adult population owned 72% of the country's household wealth, while the bottom 50% owned just 2%.[[357]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-377)
triples.statement: Wealth in the United States is highly concentrated; in 2011, the top 10% of adults owned 72% of household wealth, while the bottom 50% owned only 2%.

triples.sentence: In 2024, the country had some of the highest wealth and income inequality levels among [OECD](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OECD "OECD") countries.[[360]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-380)
triples.statement: In 2024, the U.S. had some of the highest levels of wealth and income inequality among OECD countries.

triples.sentence: There were about 771,480 [homeless persons in the U.S.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homelessness_in_the_United_States "Homelessness in the United States") in 2024.[[364]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-384)
triples.statement: In 2024, there were approximately 771,480 homeless people in the U.S.

triples.sentence: In 2022, 6.4 million children experienced food insecurity.[[365]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-ers.usda.gov-385)
triples.statement: In 2022, 6.4 million children in the U.S. experienced food insecurity.

triples.sentence: [Feeding America](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feeding_America "Feeding America") estimates that around one in five, or approximately 13 million, [children experience hunger in the U.S.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hunger_in_the_United_States#Children "Hunger in the United States") and do not know where or when they will get their next meal.[[366]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FactsAbout-386)
triples.statement: Feeding America estimates that about one in five children in the U.S., roughly 13 million, experience hunger.

triples.sentence: Also in 2022, about 37.9 million people, or 11.5% of the U.S. population, were [living in poverty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Poverty_in_the_United_States "Poverty in the United States").[[367]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-387)
triples.statement: In 2022, approximately 37.9 million people, or 11.5% of the population, were living in poverty in the U.S.

triples.sentence: It is the only [advanced economy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Advanced_economy "Advanced economy") that does not [guarantee its workers paid vacation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_statutory_minimum_employment_leave_by_country "List of statutory minimum employment leave by country") nationally[[370]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-390) and one of a few countries in the world without federal [paid family leave](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parental_leave_in_the_United_States "Parental leave in the United States") as a legal right.[[371]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-391)
triples.statement: The U.S. is the only advanced economy without a national guarantee of paid vacation for workers and is one of the few countries without federally mandated paid family leave.

section_body:
Main articles: [Science and technology in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_the_United_States "Science and technology in the United States") and [Science policy of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Science_policy_of_the_United_States "Science policy of the United States")

[![Image 54](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Aerial_view_of_Silicon_Valley.jpg/250px-Aerial_view_of_Silicon_Valley.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Aerial_view_of_Silicon_Valley.jpg)

California's [Silicon Valley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Silicon_Valley "Silicon Valley") is the largest and foremost technology and innovation hub in the world.[[373]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-393)[[374]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-394)

The United States [has been a leader in technological innovation since the late 19th century](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_and_industrial_history_of_the_United_States "Technological and industrial history of the United States") and scientific research since the mid-20th century.[[375]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-395) Methods for producing [interchangeable parts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interchangeable_parts "Interchangeable parts") and the establishment of a [machine tool](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine_tool "Machine tool") industry enabled [the large-scale manufacturing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_system_of_manufacturing "American system of manufacturing") of U.S. consumer products in the late 19th century.[[376]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-396) By the early 20th century, factory [electrification](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electrification "Electrification"), the introduction of the [assembly line](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assembly_line "Assembly line"), and other [labor-saving techniques](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automation "Automation") created the system of [mass production](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mass_production "Mass production").[[377]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-397)

In the 21st century, the United States continues to be one of the world's foremost scientific powers,[[378]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-398) though China has emerged as a major competitor in many fields.[[379]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-399) The U.S. has the [highest research and development expenditures of any country](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_sovereign_states_by_research_and_development_spending "List of sovereign states by research and development spending")[[380]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-400) and ranks ninth as a percentage of GDP.[[381]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-401) In 2022, the United States was (after China) the country with the [second-highest number of published scientific papers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_scientific_and_technical_journal_articles "List of countries by number of scientific and technical journal articles").[[382]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-402) In 2021, the U.S. ranked second (also after China) by the number of patent applications, and third by trademark and industrial design applications (after China and Germany), according to [World Intellectual Property Indicators](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Intellectual_Property_Indicators "World Intellectual Property Indicators").[[383]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-403) In 2025[[384]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-404)[[385]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-405) the United States ranked third (after Switzerland and Sweden) in the [Global Innovation Index](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Global_Innovation_Index "Global Innovation Index"). The United States is considered to be the leading country in the development of [artificial intelligence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence "Artificial intelligence") technology.[[386]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-406) In 2023, the United States was ranked the second most technologically advanced country in the world (after South Korea) by _[Global Finance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Global\_Finance\_(magazine) "Global Finance (magazine)")_ magazine.[[387]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-407)

triples.sentence: California's [Silicon Valley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Silicon_Valley "Silicon Valley") is the largest and foremost technology and innovation hub in the world.[[373]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-393)[[374]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-394)
triples.statement: California's Silicon Valley is the world's largest and most prominent technology and innovation hub.

triples.sentence: The United States [has been a leader in technological innovation since the late 19th century](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_and_industrial_history_of_the_United_States "Technological and industrial history of the United States") and scientific research since the mid-20th century.[[375]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-395)
triples.statement: The United States has been a leader in technological innovation since the late 19th century and in scientific research since the mid-20th century.

triples.sentence: Methods for producing [interchangeable parts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interchangeable_parts "Interchangeable parts") and the establishment of a [machine tool](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine_tool "Machine tool") industry enabled [the large-scale manufacturing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_system_of_manufacturing "American system of manufacturing") of U.S. consumer products in the late 19th century.[[376]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-396)
triples.statement: The development of interchangeable parts and a machine tool industry in the late 19th century enabled the large-scale manufacturing of U.S. consumer products.

triples.sentence: By the early 20th century, factory [electrification](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electrification "Electrification"), the introduction of the [assembly line](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assembly_line "Assembly line"), and other [labor-saving techniques](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automation "Automation") created the system of [mass production](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mass_production "Mass production").[[377]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-397)
triples.statement: By the early 20th century, factory electrification, the assembly line, and other labor-saving techniques led to the creation of the mass production system.

triples.sentence: In the 21st century, the United States continues to be one of the world's foremost scientific powers,[[378]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-398) though China has emerged as a major competitor in many fields.[[379]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-399)
triples.statement: In the 21st century, the United States remains one of the world's leading scientific powers, although China has become a major competitor in many fields.

triples.sentence: The U.S. has the [highest research and development expenditures of any country](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_sovereign_states_by_research_and_development_spending "List of sovereign states by research and development spending")[[380]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-400) and ranks ninth as a percentage of GDP.[[381]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-401)
triples.statement: The U.S. has the highest research and development expenditures of any country and ranks ninth when measured as a percentage of GDP.

triples.sentence: In 2022, the United States was (after China) the country with the [second-highest number of published scientific papers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_scientific_and_technical_journal_articles "List of countries by number of scientific and technical journal articles").[[382]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-402)
triples.statement: In 2022, the United States published the second-highest number of scientific papers, following China.

triples.sentence: In 2021, the U.S. ranked second (also after China) by the number of patent applications, and third by trademark and industrial design applications (after China and Germany), according to [World Intellectual Property Indicators](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Intellectual_Property_Indicators "World Intellectual Property Indicators").[[383]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-403)
triples.statement: In 2021, the U.S. ranked second in patent applications (after China) and third in trademark and industrial design applications (after China and Germany).

triples.sentence: In 2025[[384]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-404)[[385]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-405) the United States ranked third (after Switzerland and Sweden) in the [Global Innovation Index](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Global_Innovation_Index "Global Innovation Index").
triples.statement: In 2025, the United States ranked third in the Global Innovation Index, behind Switzerland and Sweden.

triples.sentence: The United States is considered to be the leading country in the development of [artificial intelligence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence "Artificial intelligence") technology.[[386]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-406)
triples.statement: The United States is considered the leading country in the development of artificial intelligence technology.

triples.sentence: In 2023, the United States was ranked the second most technologically advanced country in the world (after South Korea) by _[Global Finance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Global\_Finance\_(magazine) "Global Finance (magazine)")_ magazine.[[387]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-407)
triples.statement: In 2023, Global Finance magazine ranked the United States as the world's second most technologically advanced country, after South Korea.

section_body:
Main article: [Space policy of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_policy_of_the_United_States "Space policy of the United States")

[![Image 55](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/A_Man_on_the_Moon%2C_AS11-40-5903_%28cropped%29.jpg/250px-A_Man_on_the_Moon%2C_AS11-40-5903_%28cropped%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:A_Man_on_the_Moon,_AS11-40-5903_(cropped).jpg)

Astronauts [Buzz Aldrin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buzz_Aldrin "Buzz Aldrin") and [Neil Armstrong](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neil_Armstrong "Neil Armstrong") (seen in visor reflection) during the 1969 [Apollo 11](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apollo_11 "Apollo 11") mission, the first crewed [Moon landing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moon_landing "Moon landing"). The United States is the only country to have landed humans on the Moon.

The United States has maintained a space program since the late 1950s, beginning with the establishment of the [National Aeronautics and Space Administration](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NASA "NASA") (NASA) in 1958.[[388]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-408)[[389]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-409) NASA's [Apollo program](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apollo_program "Apollo program") (1961–1972) achieved the first crewed [Moon landing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moon_landing "Moon landing") with the 1969 [Apollo 11](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apollo_11 "Apollo 11") mission; it remains one of the agency's most significant milestones.[[390]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-410)[[391]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-411) Other major endeavors by NASA include the [Space Shuttle program](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Shuttle_program "Space Shuttle program") (1981–2011),[[392]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-412) the [Voyager program](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voyager_program "Voyager program") (1972–present), the [Hubble](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hubble_Space_Telescope "Hubble Space Telescope") and [James Webb](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Webb_Space_Telescope "James Webb Space Telescope")[space telescopes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_telescope "Space telescope") (launched in 1990 and 2021, respectively),[[393]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-413)[[394]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-414) and the multi-mission [Mars Exploration Program](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mars_Exploration_Program "Mars Exploration Program") (_[Spirit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mars\_Exploration\_Rover "Mars Exploration Rover")_ and _[Opportunity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opportunity\_(rover) "Opportunity (rover)")_, _[Curiosity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Curiosity\_(rover) "Curiosity (rover)"),_ and _[Perseverance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perseverance\_(rover) "Perseverance (rover)")_).[[395]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-415) NASA is one of five agencies collaborating on the [International Space Station](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Space_Station "International Space Station") (ISS);[[396]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-416) U.S. contributions to the ISS include several modules, including _[Destiny](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Destiny\_(ISS\_module) "Destiny (ISS module)")_ (2001), _[Harmony](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harmony\_(ISS\_module) "Harmony (ISS module)")_ (2007), and _[Tranquility](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tranquility\_(ISS\_module) "Tranquility (ISS module)")_ (2010), as well as ongoing logistical and operational support.[[397]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-417)

The United States [private sector](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Private_sector "Private sector") dominates the global [commercial spaceflight industry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Private_spaceflight "Private spaceflight").[[398]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-418) Prominent American spaceflight contractors include [Blue Origin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blue_Origin "Blue Origin"), [Boeing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing "Boeing"), [Lockheed Martin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lockheed_Martin "Lockheed Martin"), [Northrop Grumman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northrop_Grumman "Northrop Grumman"), and [SpaceX](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SpaceX "SpaceX"). NASA programs such as the [Commercial Crew Program](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commercial_Crew_Program "Commercial Crew Program"), [Commercial Resupply Services](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commercial_Resupply_Services "Commercial Resupply Services"), [Commercial Lunar Payload Services](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commercial_Lunar_Payload_Services "Commercial Lunar Payload Services"), and [NextSTEP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Next_Space_Technologies_for_Exploration_Partnerships "Next Space Technologies for Exploration Partnerships") have facilitated growing private-sector involvement in American spaceflight.[[399]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-419)

triples.sentence: The United States has maintained a space program since the late 1950s, beginning with the establishment of the [National Aeronautics and Space Administration](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NASA "NASA") (NASA) in 1958.[[388]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-408)[[389]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-409)
triples.statement: The United States has had a space program since the late 1950s, starting with the establishment of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) in 1958.

triples.sentence: Other major endeavors by NASA include the [Space Shuttle program](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Shuttle_program "Space Shuttle program") (1981–2011),[[392]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-412) the [Voyager program](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voyager_program "Voyager program") (1972–present), the [Hubble](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hubble_Space_Telescope "Hubble Space Telescope") and [James Webb](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Webb_Space_Telescope "James Webb Space Telescope")[space telescopes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_telescope "Space telescope") (launched in 1990 and 2021, respectively),[[393]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-413)[[394]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-414) and the multi-mission [Mars Exploration Program](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mars_Exploration_Program "Mars Exploration Program") (_[Spirit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mars_Exploration_Rover "Mars Exploration Rover")_ and _[Opportunity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opportunity_(rover) "Opportunity (rover)")_, _[Curiosity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Curiosity_(rover) "Curiosity (rover)"),_ and _[Perseverance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perseverance_(rover) "Perseverance (rover)")_).[[395]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-415)
triples.statement: Other major NASA endeavors include the Space Shuttle program (1981–2011), the Voyager program (1972–present), the Hubble and James Webb space telescopes (launched in 1990 and 2021), and the Mars Exploration Program (featuring rovers like Spirit, Opportunity, Curiosity, and Perseverance).

triples.sentence: NASA is one of five agencies collaborating on the [International Space Station](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Space_Station "International Space Station") (ISS);[[396]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-416) U.S. contributions to the ISS include several modules, including _[Destiny](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Destiny_(ISS_module) "Destiny (ISS module)")_ (2001), _[Harmony](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harmony_(ISS_module) "Harmony (ISS module)")_ (2007), and _[Tranquility](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tranquility_(ISS_module) "Tranquility (ISS module)")_ (2010), as well as ongoing logistical and operational support.[[397]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-417)
triples.statement: NASA is one of five agencies collaborating on the International Space Station (ISS), to which the U.S. has contributed several modules (including Destiny, Harmony, and Tranquility) and provides ongoing support.

triples.sentence: The United States [private sector](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Private_sector "Private sector") dominates the global [commercial spaceflight industry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Private_spaceflight "Private spaceflight").[[398]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-418)
triples.statement: The private sector in the United States dominates the global commercial spaceflight industry.

triples.sentence: NASA programs such as the [Commercial Crew Program](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commercial_Crew_Program "Commercial Crew Program"), [Commercial Resupply Services](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commercial_Resupply_Services "Commercial Resupply Services"), [Commercial Lunar Payload Services](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commercial_Lunar_Payload_Services "Commercial Lunar Payload Services"), and [NextSTEP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Next_Space_Technologies_for_Exploration_Partnerships "Next Space Technologies for Exploration Partnerships") have facilitated growing private-sector involvement in American spaceflight.[[399]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-419)
triples.statement: NASA programs like the Commercial Crew Program, Commercial Resupply Services, Commercial Lunar Payload Services, and NextSTEP have helped increase private-sector involvement in American spaceflight.

section_body:
Main article: [Energy in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Energy_in_the_United_States "Energy in the United States")

In 2023, the United States received approximately 84% of its energy from fossil fuel, and its largest source of energy was [petroleum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Petroleum_in_the_United_States "Petroleum in the United States") (38%), followed by [natural gas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_gas_in_the_United_States "Natural gas in the United States") (36%), [renewable sources](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Renewable_energy_in_the_United_States "Renewable energy in the United States") (9%), [coal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coal_in_the_United_States "Coal in the United States") (9%), and [nuclear power](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nuclear_power_in_the_United_States "Nuclear power in the United States") (9%).[[400]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-420)[[401]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-visu-421) In 2022, the United States constituted about 4% of the [world's population](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_population "World population"), but [consumed around 16%](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_energy_consumption "List of countries by energy consumption") of the [world's energy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_energy_consumption "World energy consumption").[[402]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-422) The U.S. ranks as the [second-highest emitter of greenhouse gases](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_greenhouse_gas_emissions "List of countries by greenhouse gas emissions") behind China.[[403]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-423)

The U.S. is the world's [largest producer of nuclear power](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nuclear_power_by_country "Nuclear power by country"), generating around 30% of the world's nuclear electricity.[[404]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-424) It also has the highest number of nuclear power reactors of any country.[[405]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-425) From 2024, the U.S. plans to triple its nuclear power capacity by 2050.[[406]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-426)

triples.sentence: In 2023, the United States received approximately 84% of its energy from fossil fuel, and its largest source of energy was [petroleum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Petroleum_in_the_United_States "Petroleum in the United States") (38%), followed by [natural gas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_gas_in_the_United_States "Natural gas in the United States") (36%), [renewable sources](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Renewable_energy_in_the_United_States "Renewable energy in the United States") (9%), [coal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coal_in_the_United_States "Coal in the United States") (9%), and [nuclear power](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nuclear_power_in_the_United_States "Nuclear power in the United States") (9%).[[400]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-420)[[401]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-visu-421)
triples.statement: In 2023, the United States sourced approximately 84% of its energy from fossil fuels, with the breakdown being petroleum (38%), natural gas (36%), renewable sources (9%), coal (9%), and nuclear power (9%).

triples.sentence: In 2022, the United States constituted about 4% of the [world's population](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_population "World population"), but [consumed around 16%](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_energy_consumption "List of countries by energy consumption") of the [world's energy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_energy_consumption "World energy consumption").[[402]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-422)
triples.statement: In 2022, the United States, with about 4% of the world's population, consumed around 16% of the world's energy.

triples.sentence: The U.S. ranks as the [second-highest emitter of greenhouse gases](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_greenhouse_gas_emissions "List of countries by greenhouse gas emissions") behind China.[[403]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-423)
triples.statement: The U.S. is the second-highest emitter of greenhouse gases, after China.

triples.sentence: The U.S. is the world's [largest producer of nuclear power](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nuclear_power_by_country "Nuclear power by country"), generating around 30% of the world's nuclear electricity.[[404]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-424)
triples.statement: The U.S. is the world's largest producer of nuclear power, generating about 30% of the world's nuclear electricity.

triples.sentence: It also has the highest number of nuclear power reactors of any country.[[405]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-425)
triples.statement: The U.S. has the highest number of nuclear power reactors of any country.

triples.sentence: From 2024, the U.S. plans to triple its nuclear power capacity by 2050.[[406]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-426)
triples.statement: Starting in 2024, the U.S. plans to triple its nuclear power capacity by 2050.

section_body:
Main article: [Transportation in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transportation_in_the_United_States "Transportation in the United States")

[![Image 56](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/45intoI-10_2.jpg/250px-45intoI-10_2.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:45intoI-10_2.jpg)

Interchange between [Interstate 10](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interstate_10 "Interstate 10") and [Interstate 45](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interstate_45 "Interstate 45") in [Houston](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Houston "Houston"), Texas

The United States' 4 million miles (6.4 million kilometers) of road network, owned almost entirely by state and local governments, is the [longest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_road_network_size "List of countries by road network size") in the world.[[407]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-427)[[408]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-428) The extensive [Interstate Highway System](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interstate_Highway_System "Interstate Highway System") that connects all major U.S. cities is funded mostly by the federal government but maintained by [state departments of transportation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_U.S._state_and_insular_area_departments_of_transportation "List of U.S. state and insular area departments of transportation"). The system is further extended by [state highways](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_highway#United_States "State highway") and some private [toll roads](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toll_road "Toll road").

The U.S. is among the top ten countries with the [highest vehicle ownership per capita](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_vehicles_per_capita "List of countries by vehicles per capita") (850 vehicles per 1,000 people) in 2022. A 2022 study found that 76% of U.S. commuters drive alone and 14% ride a bicycle, including bike owners and users of [bike-sharing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bike-sharing "Bike-sharing") networks. About 11% use some form of public transportation.[[409]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-429)[[410]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-430)

[Public transportation in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_transportation_in_the_United_States "Public transportation in the United States") is well developed in the largest urban areas, notably New York City, Washington, D.C., Boston, Philadelphia, Chicago, and San Francisco; otherwise, coverage is generally less extensive than in most other developed countries. The U.S. also has many relatively [car-dependent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Car-dependent "Car-dependent") localities.[[411]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-431)

Long-distance intercity travel is provided primarily by airlines, but travel by rail is more common along the [Northeast Corridor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northeast_Corridor "Northeast Corridor"), the only [high-speed rail in the U.S.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/High-speed_rail_in_the_United_States "High-speed rail in the United States") that meets international standards. [Amtrak](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amtrak "Amtrak"), the country's government-sponsored national passenger rail company, has a relatively sparse network compared to that of Western European countries. Service is concentrated in the Northeast, California, the Midwest, the Pacific Northwest, and Virginia/Southeast.

[![Image 57](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/ATL%281%29_%28cropped%29.jpg/250px-ATL%281%29_%28cropped%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:ATL(1)_(cropped).jpg)

[Hartsfield–Jackson Atlanta International Airport](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hartsfield%E2%80%93Jackson_Atlanta_International_Airport "Hartsfield–Jackson Atlanta International Airport"), serving the [Atlanta metropolitan area](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atlanta_metropolitan_area "Atlanta metropolitan area"), is the world's [busiest airport by passenger traffic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_busiest_airports_by_passenger_traffic "List of busiest airports by passenger traffic") with over 75 million passengers as of 2021.[[412]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-BusyAirport-432)[[413]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-433)

The United States has an extensive air transportation network. [U.S. civilian airlines](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_airlines_of_the_United_States "List of airlines of the United States") are all privately owned. The three largest airlines in the world, by total number of passengers carried, are U.S.-based; [American Airlines](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Airlines "American Airlines") became the global leader after its 2013 merger with [US Airways](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/US_Airways "US Airways").[[414]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-434) Of the 50 busiest airports in the world, 16 are in the United States, as well as five of the top 10.[[415]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-PANYNJ_2021_report-435) The world's busiest airport by passenger volume is [Hartsfield–Jackson Atlanta International](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hartsfield%E2%80%93Jackson_Atlanta_International_Airport "Hartsfield–Jackson Atlanta International Airport") in [Atlanta, Georgia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atlanta "Atlanta").[[412]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-BusyAirport-432)[[415]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-PANYNJ_2021_report-435) In 2022, most of the [19,969 U.S. airports](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_airports_in_the_United_States "List of airports in the United States")[[416]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-436) were owned and operated by local government authorities, and there are also some private airports. Some 5,193 are designated as "public use", including for [general aviation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/General_aviation "General aviation"). The [Transportation Security Administration](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transportation_Security_Administration "Transportation Security Administration") (TSA) has provided security at most major airports since 2001.

[The country's rail transport network](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rail_transport_in_the_United_States "Rail transport in the United States"), the [longest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_rail_transport_network_size "List of countries by rail transport network size") in the world at 182,412.3 mi (293,564.2 km),[[417]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-437) handles mostly [freight](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freight_transport "Freight transport")[[418]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-438)[[419]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-439) (in contrast to more passenger-centered rail in Europe[[420]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-440)). Because they are often privately owned operations, U.S. railroads lag behind those of the rest of the world in terms of electrification.[[421]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-441)

[The country's inland waterways](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inland_waterways_of_the_United_States "Inland waterways of the United States") are the world's [fifth-longest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_waterways_length "List of countries by waterways length"), totaling 25,482 mi (41,009 km).[[422]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-442) They are used extensively for freight, recreation, and a small amount of passenger traffic. Of the world's [50 busiest container ports](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_busiest_container_ports "List of busiest container ports"), four are located in the United States, with the busiest in the country being the [Port of Los Angeles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Port_of_Los_Angeles "Port of Los Angeles").[[423]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-443)

triples.sentence: The United States' 4 million miles (6.4 million kilometers) of road network, owned almost entirely by state and local governments, is the [longest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_road_network_size "List of countries by road network size") in the world.[[407]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-427)[[408]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-428)
triples.statement: The United States has the world's longest road network at 4 million miles (6.4 million kilometers), which is almost entirely owned by state and local governments.

triples.sentence: About 11% use some form of public transportation.[[409]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-429)[[410]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-430)
triples.statement: Approximately 11% of U.S. commuters use some form of public transportation.

triples.sentence: The U.S. also has many relatively [car-dependent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Car-dependent "Car-dependent") localities.[[411]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-431)
triples.statement: The U.S. has many localities that are relatively car-dependent.

triples.statement: Hartsfield–Jackson Atlanta International Airport, which serves the Atlanta metropolitan area, was the world's busiest airport by passenger traffic in 2021 with over 75 million passengers.

triples.sentence: The three largest airlines in the world, by total number of passengers carried, are U.S.-based; [American Airlines](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Airlines "American Airlines") became the global leader after its 2013 merger with [US Airways](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/US_Airways "US Airways").[[414]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-434)
triples.statement: The three largest airlines in the world by passenger volume are U.S.-based, with American Airlines becoming the largest after its 2013 merger with US Airways.

triples.sentence: Of the 50 busiest airports in the world, 16 are in the United States, as well as five of the top 10.[[415]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-PANYNJ_2021_report-435)
triples.statement: Sixteen of the world's 50 busiest airports, including five of the top 10, are located in the United States.

triples.sentence: The world's busiest airport by passenger volume is [Hartsfield–Jackson Atlanta International](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hartsfield%E2%80%93Jackson_Atlanta_International_Airport "Hartsfield–Jackson Atlanta International Airport") in [Atlanta, Georgia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atlanta "Atlanta").[[412]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-BusyAirport-432)[[415]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-PANYNJ_2021_report-435)
triples.statement: The busiest airport in the world by passenger volume is Hartsfield–Jackson Atlanta International in Atlanta, Georgia.

triples.sentence: In 2022, most of the [19,969 U.S. airports](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_airports_in_the_United_States "List of airports in the United States")[[416]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-436) were owned and operated by local government authorities, and there are also some private airports.
triples.statement: In 2022, most of the 19,969 U.S. airports were owned and operated by local government authorities, with some being privately owned.

triples.sentence: [The country's rail transport network](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rail_transport_in_the_United_States "Rail transport in the United States"), the [longest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_rail_transport_network_size "List of countries by rail transport network size") in the world at 182,412.3 mi (293,564.2 km),[[417]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-437) handles mostly [freight](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freight_transport "Freight transport")[[418]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-438)[[419]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-439) (in contrast to more passenger-centered rail in Europe[[420]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-440)).
triples.statement: The U.S. rail transport network, the world's longest at 182,412.3 miles, primarily handles freight, unlike the more passenger-focused rail systems in Europe.

triples.sentence: Because they are often privately owned operations, U.S. railroads lag behind those of the rest of the world in terms of electrification.[[421]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-441)
triples.statement: Due to being largely privately owned, U.S. railroads have less electrification compared to those in other parts of the world.

triples.sentence: [The country's inland waterways](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inland_waterways_of_the_United_States "Inland waterways of the United States") are the world's [fifth-longest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_waterways_length "List of countries by waterways length"), totaling 25,482 mi (41,009 km).[[422]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-442)
triples.statement: The inland waterways of the United States are the fifth-longest in the world, with a total length of 25,482 miles (41,009 km).

triples.sentence: Of the world's [50 busiest container ports](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_busiest_container_ports "List of busiest container ports"), four are located in the United States, with the busiest in the country being the [Port of Los Angeles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Port_of_Los_Angeles "Port of Los Angeles").[[423]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-443)
triples.statement: Four of the world's 50 busiest container ports are in the United States, with the Port of Los Angeles being the busiest in the country.

section_body:
Main articles: [Americans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Americans "Americans") and [Race and ethnicity in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Race_and_ethnicity_in_the_United_States "Race and ethnicity in the United States")

See also: [List of U.S. states by population](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_U.S._states_by_population "List of U.S. states by population")

The 10 most populous U.S. states 

 (2024 estimates)[[424]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-CensusEst2024-444)| State | Population (millions) |
| --- | --- |
| [California](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/California "California") | 39.4 |
| [Texas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Texas "Texas") | 31.3 |
| [Florida](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Florida "Florida") | 23.4 |
| [New York](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_(state) "New York (state)") | 19.9 |
| [Pennsylvania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pennsylvania "Pennsylvania") | 13.1 |
| [Illinois](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Illinois "Illinois") | 12.7 |
| [Ohio](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ohio "Ohio") | 11.9 |
| [Georgia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Georgia_(U.S._state) "Georgia (U.S. state)") | 11.2 |
| [North Carolina](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_Carolina "North Carolina") | 11.0 |
| [Michigan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michigan "Michigan") | 10.1 |

The [U.S. Census Bureau](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Census_Bureau "United States Census Bureau") reported 331,449,281 residents on April 1, 2020,[[u]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-445)[[425]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-2020CENSUS-446) making the United States the [third-most-populous country](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_population "List of countries and dependencies by population") in the world, after China and India.[[345]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-CIA-2018-364) The Census Bureau's official 2024 population estimate was 340,110,988, an increase of 2.6% since the 2020 census.[[13]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Vintage2024-16) According to the Bureau's [U.S. Population Clock](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.S._and_World_Population_Clock "U.S. and World Population Clock"), on July 1, 2024, the U.S. population had a net gain of one person every 16 seconds, or about 5400 people per day.[[426]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-447) In 2023, 51% of Americans age 15 and over were married, 6% were [widowed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Widowed "Widowed"), 10% were divorced, and 34% had never been married.[[427]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-448) In 2023, the [total fertility rate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Total_fertility_rate "Total fertility rate") for the U.S. stood at 1.6 children per woman,[[428]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-449) and, at 23%, it had the world's highest rate of children living in [single-parent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Single_parents_in_the_United_States "Single parents in the United States") households in 2019.[[429]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-450)

The United States has a diverse population; 37 [ancestry groups](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_ancestries "American ancestries") have more than one million members.[[430]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-An2000-451)[White Americans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-Hispanic_whites "Non-Hispanic whites") with ancestry from Europe, the Middle East, or North Africa form the largest [racial](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Race_(human_classification) "Race (human classification)") and [ethnic group](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethnic_group "Ethnic group") at 57.8% of the United States population.[[431]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-452)[[432]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-453)[Hispanic and Latino Americans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hispanic_and_Latino_Americans "Hispanic and Latino Americans") form the second-largest group and are 18.7% of the United States population. [African Americans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/African_Americans "African Americans") constitute the country's third-largest ancestry group and are 12.1% of the total U.S. population.[[430]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-An2000-451) Asian Americans are the country's fourth-largest group, composing 5.9% of the United States population. The country's 3.7 million Native Americans account for about 1%,[[430]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-An2000-451) and some 574 native tribes are recognized by the federal government.[[433]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-454) In 2024, the [median age](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Median_age "Median age") of the United States population was 39.1 years.[[434]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-455)
