triples.statement: The U.S. healthcare system spends more than any other country, both per capita and as a percentage of GDP, but achieves worse healthcare outcomes compared to peer countries.

triples.sentence: The United States is the only developed country [without a system of universal healthcare](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Healthcare_reform_in_the_United_States "Healthcare reform in the United States"), and [a significant proportion of the population that does not carry health insurance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Health_insurance_coverage_in_the_United_States "Health insurance coverage in the United States").[[475]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-497)
triples.statement: The United States is the only developed country without a universal healthcare system, and a significant portion of its population does not have health insurance.

triples.sentence: [Abortion in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abortion_in_the_United_States "Abortion in the United States") is not federally protected, and is illegal or restricted in 17 states.[[477]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-500)
triples.statement: Abortion in the United States lacks federal protection and is illegal or restricted in 17 states.

section_body:
Main article: [Education in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Education_in_the_United_States "Education in the United States")

[![Image 61: Photograph of the University of Virginia](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/University_of_Virginia_Rotunda_in_2006.jpg/250px-University_of_Virginia_Rotunda_in_2006.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:University_of_Virginia_Rotunda_in_2006.jpg)

Some 77% of American college students attend public institutions[[478]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-501) such as the [University of Virginia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Virginia "University of Virginia"), founded by [Thomas Jefferson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Jefferson "Thomas Jefferson") in 1819.

American primary and secondary education, known in the U.S. as [K–12](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/K%E2%80%9312_education_in_the_United_States "K–12 education in the United States") ("kindergarten through 12th grade"), is decentralized. School systems are operated by state, territorial, and sometimes municipal governments and regulated by the [U.S. Department of Education](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Education "United States Department of Education"). In general, children are required to attend school or [an approved homeschool](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homeschooling_in_the_United_States "Homeschooling in the United States") from the age of five or six ([kindergarten](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kindergarten "Kindergarten") or [first grade](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_grade "First grade")) until they are 18 years old. This often brings students through the [12th grade](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twelfth_grade "Twelfth grade"), the final year of a U.S. high school, but some states and territories allow them to leave school earlier, at age 16 or 17.[[479]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-502) The U.S. spends more on education per student than any other country,[[480]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-503) an average of $18,614 per year per public elementary and secondary school student in 2020–2021.[[481]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-504) Among Americans age 25 and older, 92.2% graduated from high school, 62.7% attended some college, 37.7% earned a [bachelor's degree](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bachelor%27s_degree "Bachelor's degree"), and 14.2% earned a graduate degree.[[482]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-505) The [U.S. literacy rate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Literacy_in_the_United_States "Literacy in the United States") is near-universal.[[345]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-CIA-2018-364)[[483]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-506) The U.S. has produced the [most Nobel Prize winners of any country](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Nobel_laureates_by_country "List of Nobel laureates by country"), with [411](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_American_Nobel_laureates "List of American Nobel laureates") (having won 413 awards).[[484]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-507)[[485]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-508)

[U.S. tertiary or higher education](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Higher_education_in_the_United_States "Higher education in the United States") has earned a global reputation. Many of the world's top universities, as listed by various ranking organizations, are in the United States, including 19 of the top 25.[[486]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-509)[[487]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-510) American higher education is dominated by [state university systems](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_university_system "State university system"), although [the country's many private universities and colleges](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Private_universities_in_the_United_States "Private universities in the United States") enroll about 20% of all American students. Local [community colleges](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Community_colleges_in_the_United_States "Community colleges in the United States") generally offer [open admissions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_admissions "Open admissions"), lower tuition, and coursework leading to a two-year [associate degree](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Associate_degree "Associate degree") or a [non-degree certificate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Certificate_program "Certificate program").[[488]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-511)

As for [public expenditures](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_expenditure "Public expenditure") on higher education, the U.S. spends more per student than the [OECD](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OECD "OECD") average, and Americans spend more than all nations in combined public and private spending.[[489]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-education_spending-512) Colleges and universities directly funded by the federal government do not charge tuition and are limited to military personnel and government employees, including: the [U.S. service academies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_service_academies "United States service academies"), the [Naval Postgraduate School](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Naval_Postgraduate_School "Naval Postgraduate School"), and [military staff colleges](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/US_military_staff_colleges "US military staff colleges"). Despite some student [loan forgiveness](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Loan_forgiveness "Loan forgiveness") programs in place,[[490]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-513)[student loan debt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Student_debt "Student debt") increased by 102% between 2010 and 2020,[[491]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-514) and exceeded $1.7 trillion in 2022.[[492]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-515)

triples.sentence: Some 77% of American college students attend public institutions[[478]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-501) such as the [University of Virginia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Virginia "University of Virginia"), founded by [Thomas Jefferson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Jefferson "Thomas Jefferson") in 1819.
triples.statement: Approximately 77% of American college students attend public institutions like the University of Virginia, which was founded by Thomas Jefferson in 1819.

triples.sentence: This often brings students through the [12th grade](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twelfth_grade "Twelfth grade"), the final year of a U.S. high school, but some states and territories allow them to leave school earlier, at age 16 or 17.[[479]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-502)
triples.statement: While students often complete the 12th grade, some states and territories permit them to leave school earlier, at age 16 or 17.

triples.sentence: The U.S. spends more on education per student than any other country,[[480]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-503) an average of $18,614 per year per public elementary and secondary school student in 2020–2021.[[481]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-504)
triples.statement: The U.S. spends more on education per student than any other country, with an average of $18,614 per year for each public elementary and secondary school student in 2020–2021.

triples.sentence: Among Americans age 25 and older, 92.2% graduated from high school, 62.7% attended some college, 37.7% earned a [bachelor's degree](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bachelor%27s_degree "Bachelor's degree"), and 14.2% earned a graduate degree.[[482]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-505)
triples.statement: Among Americans age 25 and older, 92.2% graduated from high school, 62.7% attended some college, 37.7% earned a bachelor's degree, and 14.2% earned a graduate degree.

triples.sentence: The [U.S. literacy rate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Literacy_in_the_United_States "Literacy in the United States") is near-universal.[[345]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-CIA-2018-364)[[483]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-506)
triples.statement: The U.S. literacy rate is near-universal.

triples.sentence: The U.S. has produced the [most Nobel Prize winners of any country](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Nobel_laureates_by_country "List of Nobel laureates by country"), with [411](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_American_Nobel_laureates "List of American Nobel laureates") (having won 413 awards).[[484]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-507)[[485]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-508)
triples.statement: The U.S. has produced the most Nobel Prize winners of any country, with 411 laureates having won 413 awards.

triples.sentence: Many of the world's top universities, as listed by various ranking organizations, are in the United States, including 19 of the top 25.[[486]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-509)[[487]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-510)
triples.statement: According to various ranking organizations, many of the world's top universities are in the United States, including 19 of the top 25.

triples.sentence: Local [community colleges](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Community_colleges_in_the_United_States "Community colleges in the United States") generally offer [open admissions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_admissions "Open admissions"), lower tuition, and coursework leading to a two-year [associate degree](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Associate_degree "Associate degree") or a [non-degree certificate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Certificate_program "Certificate program").[[488]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-511)
triples.statement: Local community colleges generally offer open admissions, lower tuition, and coursework for a two-year associate degree or a non-degree certificate.

triples.sentence: As for [public expenditures](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_expenditure "Public expenditure") on higher education, the U.S. spends more per student than the [OECD](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OECD "OECD") average, and Americans spend more than all nations in combined public and private spending.[[489]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-education_spending-512)
triples.statement: Regarding public expenditures on higher education, the U.S. spends more per student than the OECD average and more than all other nations in combined public and private spending.

triples.sentence: Despite some student [loan forgiveness](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Loan_forgiveness "Loan forgiveness") programs in place,[[490]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-513)[student loan debt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Student_debt "Student debt") increased by 102% between 2010 and 2020,[[491]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-514) and exceeded $1.7 trillion in 2022.[[492]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-515)
triples.statement: Despite some student loan forgiveness programs, student loan debt increased by 102% between 2010 and 2020, exceeding $1.7 trillion in 2022.

section_body:
Main articles: [Culture of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Culture_of_the_United_States "Culture of the United States") and [Society of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Society_of_the_United_States "Society of the United States")

See also: [Human rights in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_rights_in_the_United_States "Human rights in the United States")

[![Image 62: The Statue of Liberty, a large teal bronze sculpture on a stone pedestal](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Statue_of_Liberty_frontal_2_crop.JPG/250px-Statue_of_Liberty_frontal_2_crop.JPG)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Statue_of_Liberty_frontal_2_crop.JPG)

The [Statue of Liberty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statue_of_Liberty "Statue of Liberty") (_Liberty Enlightening the World_) on [Liberty Island](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liberty_Island "Liberty Island") in [New York Harbor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_Harbor "New York Harbor") was an 1866 gift from France that has become an iconic symbol of the [American Dream](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Dream "American Dream").[[493]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-516)

The United States is home to [a wide variety of ethnic groups, traditions, and customs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multiculturalism_in_the_United_States "Multiculturalism in the United States").[[494]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-517)[[495]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-518) The country has been described as having [the values](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Americanism_(ideology) "Americanism (ideology)") of [individualism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Individualism "Individualism") and [personal autonomy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Left-libertarianism "Left-libertarianism"),[[496]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-519)[[497]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-520) as well as a strong [work ethic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Work_ethic "Work ethic")[[498]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-521) and [competitiveness](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Competition "Competition").[[499]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-522) Voluntary [altruism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Altruism "Altruism") towards others also plays a major role;[[500]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-523)[[501]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-524)[[502]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-525) according to a 2016 study by the [Charities Aid Foundation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charities_Aid_Foundation "Charities Aid Foundation"), Americans donated 1.44% of total GDP to charity—the [highest rate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_charitable_donation "List of countries by charitable donation") in the world by a large margin.[[503]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-526) Americans have traditionally [been characterized](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stereotypes_of_Americans "Stereotypes of Americans") by a unifying political belief in an "[American Creed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Creed "American Creed")" emphasizing [consent of the governed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consent_of_the_governed "Consent of the governed"), [liberty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liberty "Liberty"), [equality under the law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equality_under_the_law "Equality under the law"), [democracy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democracy "Democracy"), [social equality](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_equality "Social equality"), [property rights](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Property_rights "Property rights"), and a preference for [limited government](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Limited_government "Limited government").[[504]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-527)[[505]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-528) The U.S. has acquired significant [hard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hard_power "Hard power") and [soft power](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soft_power "Soft power") through [its diplomatic influence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_the_United_States "Foreign relations of the United States"), [economic power](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_power "Economic power"), [military alliances](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Military_alliance "Military alliance"), and [cultural exports](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cultural_exports "Cultural exports") such as [American movies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cinema_of_the_United_States "Cinema of the United States"), [music](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Music_of_the_United_States "Music of the United States"), [video games](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Video_games_in_the_United_States "Video games in the United States"), [sports](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sports_in_the_United_States "Sports in the United States"), and [food](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_cuisine "American cuisine").[[506]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-529)[[507]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-530) The influence that the United States exerts on other countries through soft power is referred to as [Americanization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Americanization "Americanization").[[508]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-531)

Nearly all present Americans or their ancestors came from [Europe, Africa, or Asia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Afro-Eurasia "Afro-Eurasia") (the "[Old World](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Old_World "Old World")") within the past five centuries.[[509]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-532)[Mainstream](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/mainstream "wikt:mainstream") American culture is a [Western culture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Western_culture "Western culture") largely derived from the [traditions of European immigrants](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_American#Culture "European American") with influences from many other sources, such as [traditions brought by slaves from Africa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/African-American_culture "African-American culture").[[510]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-533) More recent immigration from [Asia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asian_American "Asian American") and especially [Latin America](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin_American_culture "Latin American culture") has added to a cultural mix that has been described as a homogenizing [melting pot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Melting_pot "Melting pot"), and a heterogeneous [salad bowl](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Salad_bowl_(cultural_idea) "Salad bowl (cultural idea)"), with immigrants contributing to, and often [assimilating](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assimilation_(phonology) "Assimilation (phonology)") into, mainstream American culture.

Under the [First Amendment to the Constitution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution "First Amendment to the United States Constitution"), the United States is considered to have the [strongest protections of free speech of any country](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freedom_of_speech_in_the_United_States "Freedom of speech in the United States").[[511]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Coleman-2013-534)[Flag desecration](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flag_desecration_in_the_United_States "Flag desecration in the United States"), [hate speech](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hate_speech_in_the_United_States "Hate speech in the United States"), [blasphemy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blasphemy_law_in_the_United_States "Blasphemy law in the United States"), and [lese majesty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/L%C3%A8se-majest%C3%A9 "Lèse-majesté") are all forms of protected expression.[[512]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-535)[[513]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-536)[[514]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-537) A 2016 [Pew Research Center](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pew_Research_Center "Pew Research Center") poll found that Americans were the most supportive of free expression of any polity measured.[[515]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-538) Additionally, they are the "most supportive of [freedom of the press](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freedom_of_the_press_in_the_United_States "Freedom of the press in the United States") and the [right to use the Internet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Right_to_Internet_access "Right to Internet access") without government censorship".[[516]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-539) The U.S. is a [socially progressive](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cultural_liberalism "Cultural liberalism") country[[517]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-540) with [permissive](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Permissive_society "Permissive society") attitudes surrounding [human sexuality](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_sexuality "Human sexuality").[[518]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Derks-2020-541)[LGBTQ rights in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LGBTQ_rights_in_the_United_States "LGBTQ rights in the United States") are among the most advanced by global standards.[[518]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Derks-2020-541)[[519]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-542)[[520]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-543)

The [American Dream](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Dream "American Dream"), or the perception that Americans enjoy high levels of [social mobility](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Socio-economic_mobility_in_the_United_States "Socio-economic mobility in the United States"), plays a key role in attracting immigrants.[[521]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-544)[[522]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-545) Whether this perception is accurate has been a topic of debate.[[523]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-socialmobility-546)[[524]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-CAP-547)[[525]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-548) While mainstream culture holds that the United States is a [classless society](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Classless_society "Classless society"),[[526]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-549) scholars identify significant differences between [the country's social classes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_class_in_the_United_States "Social class in the United States"), affecting [socialization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Socialization "Socialization"), language, and values.[[527]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-550)[[528]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-551) Americans tend to greatly value [socioeconomic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Socioeconomics "Socioeconomics") achievement, but [being ordinary or average](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Average_Joe "Average Joe") is promoted by some as a noble condition as well.[[529]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-552)

The [National Foundation on the Arts and the Humanities](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Foundation_on_the_Arts_and_the_Humanities "National Foundation on the Arts and the Humanities") is an agency of the United States federal government that was established in 1965 with the purpose to "develop and promote a broadly conceived national policy of support for the humanities and the arts in the United States, and for institutions which preserve the cultural heritage of the United States."[[530]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-553) It is composed of four sub-agencies:

*   [National Endowment for the Arts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Endowment_for_the_Arts "National Endowment for the Arts")
*   [National Endowment for the Humanities](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Endowment_for_the_Humanities "National Endowment for the Humanities")
*   [Institute of Museum and Library Services](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Institute_of_Museum_and_Library_Services "Institute of Museum and Library Services")
*   [Federal Council on the Arts and the Humanities](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Council_on_the_Arts_and_the_Humanities "Federal Council on the Arts and the Humanities")

triples.sentence: The [Statue of Liberty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statue_of_Liberty "Statue of Liberty") (_Liberty Enlightening the World_) on [Liberty Island](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liberty_Island "Liberty Island") in [New York Harbor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_Harbor "New York Harbor") was an 1866 gift from France that has become an iconic symbol of the [American Dream](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Dream "American Dream").[[493]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-516)
triples.statement: The Statue of Liberty, a gift from France in 1866, is located on Liberty Island in New York Harbor and has become a symbol of the American Dream.

triples.sentence: Voluntary [altruism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Altruism "Altruism") towards others also plays a major role;[[500]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-523)[[501]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-524)[[502]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-525) according to a 2016 study by the [Charities Aid Foundation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charities_Aid_Foundation "Charities Aid Foundation"), Americans donated 1.44% of total GDP to charity—the [highest rate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_charitable_donation "List of countries by charitable donation") in the world by a large margin.[[503]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-526)
triples.statement: Voluntary altruism is a major value in the U.S.; a 2016 study found that Americans donated 1.44% of GDP to charity, the highest rate in the world.

triples.sentence: The U.S. has acquired significant [hard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hard_power "Hard power") and [soft power](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soft_power "Soft power") through [its diplomatic influence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_the_United_States "Foreign relations of the United States"), [economic power](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_power "Economic power"), [military alliances](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Military_alliance "Military alliance"), and [cultural exports](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cultural_exports "Cultural exports") such as [American movies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cinema_of_the_United_States "Cinema of the United States"), [music](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Music_of_the_United_States "Music of the United States"), [video games](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Video_games_in_the_United_States "Video games in the United States"), [sports](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sports_in_the_United_States "Sports in the United States"), and [food](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_cuisine "American cuisine").[[506]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-529)[[507]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-530)
triples.statement: The U.S. has gained significant hard and soft power via its diplomatic influence, economic strength, military alliances, and cultural exports like movies, music, and food.

triples.sentence: [Flag desecration](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flag_desecration_in_the_United_States "Flag desecration in the United States"), [hate speech](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hate_speech_in_the_United_States "Hate speech in the United States"), [blasphemy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blasphemy_law_in_the_United_States "Blasphemy law in the United States"), and [lese majesty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/L%C3%A8se-majest%C3%A9 "Lèse-majesté") are all forms of protected expression.[[512]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-535)[[513]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-536)[[514]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-537)
triples.statement: Flag desecration, hate speech, blasphemy, and lese majesty are all forms of protected expression in the United States.

triples.sentence: A 2016 [Pew Research Center](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pew_Research_Center "Pew Research Center") poll found that Americans were the most supportive of free expression of any polity measured.[[515]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-538)
triples.statement: A 2016 Pew Research Center poll indicated that Americans were the most supportive of free expression among all polities measured.

triples.sentence: Additionally, they are the "most supportive of [freedom of the press](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freedom_of_the_press_in_the_United_States "Freedom of the press in the United States") and the [right to use the Internet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Right_to_Internet_access "Right to Internet access") without government censorship".[[516]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-539)
triples.statement: Americans are also the most supportive of freedom of the press and the right to use the internet without government censorship.

triples.sentence: The [American Dream](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Dream "American Dream"), or the perception that Americans enjoy high levels of [social mobility](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Socio-economic_mobility_in_the_United_States "Socio-economic mobility in the United States"), plays a key role in attracting immigrants.[[521]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-544)[[522]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-545)
triples.statement: The American Dream, the idea that Americans have high social mobility, is a significant factor in attracting immigrants.

triples.sentence: Americans tend to greatly value [socioeconomic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Socioeconomics "Socioeconomics") achievement, but [being ordinary or average](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Average_Joe "Average Joe") is promoted by some as a noble condition as well.[[529]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-552)
triples.statement: While Americans highly value socioeconomic achievement, being ordinary or average is also sometimes promoted as a noble state.

triples.sentence: The [National Foundation on the Arts and the Humanities](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Foundation_on_the_Arts_and_the_Humanities "National Foundation on the Arts and the Humanities") is an agency of the United States federal government that was established in 1965 with the purpose to "develop and promote a broadly conceived national policy of support for the humanities and the arts in the United States, and for institutions which preserve the cultural heritage of the United States."[[530]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-553)
triples.statement: The National Foundation on the Arts and the Humanities is a U.S. federal agency established in 1965 to support the arts, humanities, and cultural heritage institutions.

section_body:
Main article: [American literature](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_literature "American literature")

See also: [American philosophy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_philosophy "American philosophy")

[![Image 63: Photograph of Mark Twain](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Mark_Twain_by_AF_Bradley.jpg/250px-Mark_Twain_by_AF_Bradley.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Mark_Twain_by_AF_Bradley.jpg)

[Mark Twain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mark_Twain "Mark Twain"), whom [William Faulkner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Faulkner "William Faulkner") called "the father of American literature"[[531]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-faulkner-554)

Colonial American authors were influenced by [John Locke](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Locke "John Locke") and other [Enlightenment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Age_of_Enlightenment "Age of Enlightenment") philosophers.[[532]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBaymLevine2013157%E2%80%93159-555)[[533]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTELauter1994a503%E2%80%93509-556) The [American Revolutionary Period](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Revolution "American Revolution") (1765–1783) is notable for the political writings of [Benjamin Franklin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benjamin_Franklin "Benjamin Franklin"), [Alexander Hamilton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexander_Hamilton "Alexander Hamilton"), [Thomas Paine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Paine "Thomas Paine"), and [Thomas Jefferson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Jefferson "Thomas Jefferson"). Shortly before and after the [Revolutionary War](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Revolutionary_War "American Revolutionary War"), the newspaper rose to prominence, filling a demand for anti-British national literature.[[534]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBaymLevine2013163-557)[[535]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-558) An early novel is [William Hill Brown](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Hill_Brown "William Hill Brown")'s _[The Power of Sympathy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\_Power\_of\_Sympathy "The Power of Sympathy")_, published in 1791. Writer and critic [John Neal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Neal "John Neal") in the early- to mid-19th century helped advance America toward a unique literature and culture by criticizing predecessors such as [Washington Irving](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_Irving "Washington Irving") for imitating their British counterparts, and by influencing writers such as [Edgar Allan Poe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edgar_Allan_Poe "Edgar Allan Poe"),[[536]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-559) who took American poetry and short fiction in new directions. [Ralph Waldo Emerson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ralph_Waldo_Emerson "Ralph Waldo Emerson") and [Margaret Fuller](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Margaret_Fuller "Margaret Fuller") pioneered the influential [Transcendentalism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transcendentalism "Transcendentalism") movement;[[537]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-560)[[538]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Coviello-561)[Henry David Thoreau](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_David_Thoreau "Henry David Thoreau"), author of _[Walden](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walden "Walden")_, was influenced by this movement.

The conflict surrounding [abolitionism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abolitionism_in_the_United_States "Abolitionism in the United States") inspired writers, like [Harriet Beecher Stowe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harriet_Beecher_Stowe "Harriet Beecher Stowe"), and authors of slave narratives, such as [Frederick Douglass](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frederick_Douglass "Frederick Douglass"). [Nathaniel Hawthorne](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nathaniel_Hawthorne "Nathaniel Hawthorne")'s _[The Scarlet Letter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\_Scarlet\_Letter "The Scarlet Letter")_ (1850) explored the dark side of American history, as did [Herman Melville](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Herman_Melville "Herman Melville")'s _[Moby-Dick](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moby-Dick "Moby-Dick")_ (1851). Major American poets of the 19th century [American Renaissance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Renaissance_(literature) "American Renaissance (literature)") include [Walt Whitman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walt_Whitman "Walt Whitman"), Melville, and [Emily Dickinson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emily_Dickinson "Emily Dickinson").[[539]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBaymLevine2013444%E2%80%93447-562)[[540]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTELauter1994a1228,_1233,_1260-563)[Mark Twain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mark_Twain "Mark Twain") was the first major American writer to be born in the West. [Henry James](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_James "Henry James") achieved international recognition with novels like _[The Portrait of a Lady](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\_Portrait\_of\_a\_Lady "The Portrait of a Lady")_ (1881). As literacy rates rose, periodicals published more stories centered around industrial workers, women, and the rural poor.[[541]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBaymLevine20131269%E2%80%931270-564)[[542]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTELauter1994b8%E2%80%9310-565)[Naturalism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Naturalism_(literature) "Naturalism (literature)"), [regionalism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_literary_regionalism "American literary regionalism"), and [realism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Literary_realism#UnitedStates "Literary realism") were the major literary movements of the period.[[543]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBaymLevine20131271%E2%80%931273-566)[[544]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTELauter1994b12-567)

While [modernism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Literary_modernism "Literary modernism") generally took on an international character, modernist authors working within the United States more often rooted their work in specific regions, peoples, and cultures.[[545]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBaymLevine20131850%E2%80%931851-568) Following the Great Migration to northern cities, African-American and black [West Indian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/West_Indian_Americans "West Indian Americans") authors of the [Harlem Renaissance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harlem_Renaissance "Harlem Renaissance") developed an independent tradition of literature that rebuked a history of inequality and celebrated black culture. An important cultural export during the [Jazz Age](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jazz_Age "Jazz Age"), these writings were a key influence on _[Négritude](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/N%C3%A9gritude "Négritude")_, a philosophy emerging in the 1930s among francophone writers of the [African diaspora](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/African_diaspora "African diaspora").[[546]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-569)[[547]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-570) In the 1950s, an ideal of homogeneity led many authors to attempt to write the [Great American Novel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_American_Novel "Great American Novel"),[[548]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBaymLevine20132260%E2%80%932261-571) while the [Beat Generation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beat_Generation "Beat Generation") rejected this conformity, using styles that elevated the impact of the [spoken word](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spoken_word "Spoken word") over mechanics to describe drug use, sexuality, and the failings of society.[[549]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBaymLevine20132262-572)[[550]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-573) Contemporary literature is more pluralistic than in previous eras, with the closest thing to a unifying feature being a trend toward self-conscious [experiments with language](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Experimental_literature "Experimental literature").[[551]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBaymLevine20132266%E2%80%932267-574) Twelve American laureates have won the [Nobel Prize in Literature](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Literature "Nobel Prize in Literature").[[552]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-575)

triples.sentence: Twelve American laureates have won the [Nobel Prize in Literature](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Literature "Nobel Prize in Literature").[[552]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-575)
triples.statement: Twelve American laureates have been awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature.

section_body:
Main article: [Mass media in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mass_media_in_the_United_States "Mass media in the United States")

See also: [Newspapers in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Newspapers_in_the_United_States "Newspapers in the United States"), [Television in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Television_in_the_United_States "Television in the United States"), [Broadcasting in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Broadcasting_in_the_United_States "Broadcasting in the United States"), [Public broadcasting in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_broadcasting_in_the_United_States "Public broadcasting in the United States"), [Internet in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_in_the_United_States "Internet in the United States"), [Radio in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radio_in_the_United_States "Radio in the United States"), and [Video games in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Video_games_in_the_United_States "Video games in the United States")

[![Image 64](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Comcast_Center_2018.jpg/250px-Comcast_Center_2018.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Comcast_Center_2018.jpg)

[Comcast Center](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comcast_Center "Comcast Center") in [Philadelphia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philadelphia "Philadelphia"), headquarters of [Comcast](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comcast "Comcast"), one of the world's [largest telecommunications companies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_telecommunications_companies "List of telecommunications companies") and media conglomerates

Media in the United States is [broadly uncensored](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Censorship_in_the_United_States "Censorship in the United States"), with the [First Amendment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution "First Amendment to the United States Constitution") providing significant protections, as reiterated in _[New York Times Co. v. United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New\_York\_Times\_Co.\_v.\_United\_States "New York Times Co. v. United States")_.[[511]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Coleman-2013-534) The four major broadcasters in the U.S. are the [National Broadcasting Company](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Broadcasting_Company "National Broadcasting Company") (NBC), [Columbia Broadcasting System](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Columbia_Broadcasting_System "Columbia Broadcasting System") (CBS), [American Broadcasting Company](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company "American Broadcasting Company") (ABC), and [Fox Broadcasting Company](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_Broadcasting_Company "Fox Broadcasting Company") (FOX). The four major broadcast television networks are all commercial entities. The [U.S. cable television system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cable_television_in_the_United_States "Cable television in the United States") offers hundreds of channels catering to a variety of niches.[[553]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-576) In 2021, about 83% of Americans over age 12 listened to [broadcast radio](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radio_broadcasting "Radio broadcasting"), while about 40% listened to [podcasts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Podcast "Podcast").[[554]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-577) In the prior year, there were 15,460 licensed full-power radio stations in the U.S. according to the [Federal Communications Commission](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Communications_Commission "Federal Communications Commission") (FCC).[[555]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-578) Much of the public radio broadcasting is supplied by [NPR](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NPR "NPR"), incorporated in February 1970 under the [Public Broadcasting Act of 1967](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_Broadcasting_Act_of_1967 "Public Broadcasting Act of 1967").[[556]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-579)

U.S. newspapers with a global reach and reputation include _[The Wall Street Journal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\_Wall\_Street\_Journal "The Wall Street Journal")_, _[The New York Times](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\_New\_York\_Times "The New York Times")_, _[The Washington Post](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\_Washington\_Post "The Washington Post")_, and _[USA Today](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USA\_Today "USA Today")_.[[557]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-Shaffer2006-580)[About 800 publications](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Spanish-language_newspapers_published_in_the_United_States "List of Spanish-language newspapers published in the United States") are produced in Spanish.[[558]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-581)[[559]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-582) With few exceptions, newspapers are privately owned, either by large chains such as [Gannett](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gannett_Company "Gannett Company") or [McClatchy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_McClatchy_Company "The McClatchy Company"), which own dozens or even hundreds of newspapers; by small chains that own a handful of papers; or, in an increasingly rare situation, by individuals or families. Major cities often have [alternative newspapers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alternative_newspaper "Alternative newspaper") to complement the mainstream daily papers, such as _[The Village Voice](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\_Village\_Voice "The Village Voice")_ in New York City and _[LA Weekly](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LA\_Weekly "LA Weekly")_ in Los Angeles. The five most popular websites used in the U.S. are [Google](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google_Search "Google Search"), [YouTube](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/YouTube "YouTube"), [Facebook](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Facebook "Facebook"), [Amazon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amazon_(website) "Amazon (website)"), and [Reddit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reddit "Reddit")—all of them American-owned.[[560]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-alexa-topsitesus-583)

In 2025, the U.S. was the world's [second-largest video game market by revenue](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_video_games_markets_by_country "List of video games markets by country") (after China).[[561]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-584) In 2015, the U.S. video game industry consisted of 2,457 companies that employed around 220,000 jobs and generated $30.4 billion in revenue.[[562]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-:0-585) There are 444 game publishers, developers, and hardware companies in California alone.[[563]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-586) According to the [Game Developers Conference](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_Developers_Conference "Game Developers Conference") (GDC), the U.S. is the top location for [video game development](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Video_game_development "Video game development"), with 58% of the world's [game developers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Video_game_developer "Video game developer") based there in 2025.[[564]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-587)

triples.sentence: The [U.S. cable television system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cable_television_in_the_United_States "Cable television in the United States") offers hundreds of channels catering to a variety of niches.[[553]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-576)
triples.statement: The U.S. cable television system offers hundreds of channels catering to a variety of niches.

triples.statement: In 2021, about 83% of Americans over age 12 listened to broadcast radio, while about 40% listened to podcasts.

triples.sentence: In the prior year, there were 15,460 licensed full-power radio stations in the U.S. according to the [Federal Communications Commission](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Communications_Commission "Federal Communications Commission") (FCC).[[555]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-578)
triples.statement: In 2020, there were 15,460 licensed full-power radio stations in the U.S. according to the Federal Communications Commission (FCC).

triples.sentence: The five most popular websites used in the U.S. are [Google](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google_Search "Google Search"), [YouTube](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/YouTube "YouTube"), [Facebook](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Facebook "Facebook"), [Amazon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amazon_(website) "Amazon (website)"), and [Reddit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reddit "Reddit")—all of them American-owned.[[560]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-alexa-topsitesus-583)
triples.statement: The five most popular websites used in the U.S. are Google, YouTube, Facebook, Amazon, and Reddit—all of them American-owned.

triples.sentence: In 2025, the U.S. was the world's [second-largest video game market by revenue](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_video_games_markets_by_country "List of video games markets by country") (after China).[[561]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#cite_note-584)
triples.statement: In 2025, the U.S. was the world's second-largest video game market by revenue, after China.

triples.statement: There are 444 game publishers, developers, and hardware companies in California alone.
